reviewText: Interesting concept but very poorly executed. I get that some games prioritize telling a story over having enjoyable gameplay, but Cibele basically has none. The gameplay itself is just incredibly boring, and doesn't offer the player any substance. All it consists of is playing a fictional game where you click on enemies, and nothing more. It is excruciatingly boring. This game should have just been created in the form of a short video.\n\nThe story itself is told via voice-overs and files on the player's computer. At first I thought the story would be somewhat interesting, but it is told in a terribly cringey way, which made it impossible to relate to the player character.  Having the main character say i always do my best to look anime ^_^"

reviewText: I really want to give this game a positive review, but there is a lot more cons than pros here. For what it is worth Cibele is a good idea that had a lot of potebtial, but the story itself felt very rushed,compact. The acting in the actual real life parts of the game seemed a bit stiff at times, along with a little of the voice acting(though the voice acting was good in others). If felt as though I was always waiting for the good part to start or waiting for something cheesy to happen, but it just left me with a sour unfulfilled feeling. The story ends so much faster than you think and that is fine, but the main arcs of the story are so brief  that is hard to keep up with. I liked it for what it was worth, but in the long run this game made me wanting more background to the whole situation. Don't get me wrong if you plan to buy this game it is not a bad buy, but it really leaves something to the imagination.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I like quirky, unusual games. I like alternative or unusual storytelling methods. I want female developers to succeed because their gender should make no difference whether or not their games are taken seriously. I like games that explore small, everyday things like a budding online relationship. On paper, this game looked pretty interesting.

Cibele, however, is barely even a game. Pretty much everything about it is just... poor.

I'd love to discuss the game's mechanics, but unfortunately... there are none. As the game unfolds, it alternates between three formats, over three time periods during which the 'relationship' between the girl and boy unfolds:

- a (very user unfriendly) virtual desktop, where you can browse the files, folders, emails etc. of the game's 'protagonist'. I hesitate to use that word, but I'll get onto that in a moment
- the multiplayer game that the 'protagonist' plays. If this were a Flash game hosted on Newgrounds in 1997, it would still be considered terrible by those standards. It's obviously just supposed to act as a placeholder, a window through which we see the interaction between the 'protagonist' and the guy she likes unfold. But it's one-dimensional, horribly made, ugly as sin, and just annoying to 'play'. It's basically a casual clicker game, but worse
- videos of a girl sitting at a computer in her underwear, taking photos of herself in her underwear, and doing other assorted things in her underwear. These make up a tiny portion of the tiny amount of gameplay in this 'game', but make up the vast majority of the screenshots and marketing. Doesn't take a genius to work out why (hint: underwear)

As for the story... I understand that I might not be the target demographic here (male, older than a teenager), but I found it awful to the point of grating. The girl through whom you view the events of the game is a completely one-dimensional, weak character. The's the 'protagonist' of the game only because you play 'through her eyes' - there is never a point in the game where you can make a decision that changes anything. It's entirely linear and on rails - the only reason this simulation can call itself a 'game' is because of the sequences where you play the fake game, and as above, that is awful and basically just completely pointless clicking until the game decides to move you on.

As for the guy that the 'protagonist' falls for... he's a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. He's creepy, he's overbearing, he's pushy, and completely awful. I honestly thought the game was shaping up to be a cautionary tale to tell naive girls not to talk to creeps online.

I thought there might be some intrigue to the way the story unfolds passively - you don't see every interaction between the girl and the boy, you only view their relationship via the three sequences above. For example, the second time you're looking at the girl's desktop, there are new files in her folders, showing a little of what she's done in the meantime. A better storyteller probably could have woven an interesting tale by letting the 'player' fill in missing details, but unfortunately that's not the case here either. The whole thing feels forced and completely artificial.

I understand that probably a fair bit of work went into making this game, so I didn't want to dismiss it with a one word review. But quite honestly, there's probably more content in this review than there is in the game. I'm gonna leave it here. **Don't waste your money on this thing. It's not good.**

Want to play a game that tells a story in a unique, alternative way? Try *To The Moon*, or *30 Flights of Loving*, or literally anything else. Just don't buy Cibele, it's a waste of money.

Avoid. Avoid it hard.

reviewText:
Cibele narrowly misses being a heartfelt glimpse of the innocence and vulnerability of attraction. At times, it’s an unsettlingly vicarious experience, but ultimately it falls flat; the ending in particular feels abrupt and poorly conceived. The setup oozes with potential, but as it doesn’t eventuate, I find it hard to recommend Cibele to anyone.

Further, there’s no reward, consequence, or anything to be gained for reading/viewing all content available to you—that’s especially disappointing.

The clunky interface and cumbersome mechanics are somewhat forgivable, however, if you approach this without the expectation to “play” it; you are simply a spectator.

reviewText:
Cibele is a tough game to review, because even as it provides a step forward in video game storytelling, there are many things that bring it a step backward as well.

Without spoiling anything:
It's emotionally raw and absorbingly personal, and yet it rushes through its plot to the point where it feels underdeveloped.
The game makes you think about a bunch of things that could very well stay in your head for days (if not weeks), and yet it's shorter than a TV episode if you just stick to the main plot.
The game's interface pulls you in closer into the protagonist's experience, and yet for much of the game's running time it feels like there's less interactivity and choice than your average walking simulator.

It's tough, because I want to applaud Nina Freeman (the game's developer) for making something so experimental, unique, and deeply felt, but at the same time the game's nowhere near as polished and developed as it could have been.

I can definitely see Cibele being a stepping stone for other story-based games in the future, but until then it stands as the sort of work that neither succeeds or fails at what it's trying to do - it just is.

As for whether you should grab it or not, I can honestly say that the price of the game is outrageous for a game of such a short length; it'll probably be overpriced even at 50% the crazy asking price. That being said - if you really want to play it to see how it is, I would reccomend sharing the experience with others; at the very least, then you're not just paying for a quick hour-long thing, you're paying for something you can keep bringing out and talking about with your friends. There are some very, very good things about this game that are worth apprieciating; I just can't wait to see those initial ideas be refined by other aspiring developes, or even polished up a fair deal by Freeman herself somewhere down the line.

5.5/10

reviewText:
If you don't want to spend money on this game but still want to see what it's about then check out my playthrough:

I'd give this 5/10.

I like interactive live-action stories/movies etc so it gets some points for that. Though this could have just been an indie short movie - throwing in an interactive element didn't necessarily detract or add much to it either way. Still - neat idea in the vein of Her Story and props go to the makers.

I'm not recommending the game here, though do feel a little harsh for not doing so. It's not that you would hate it, but you might as well just watch a playthrough of someone who has already paid for it as there isn't really anything unique you can bring to it because the story is linear and all playthroughs (bar the order they click on the pictures or chat logs) will be the same.

reviewText:
Well, this is something different.

This is a simple game, whose sole aim is to facilitate the feeling and atmosphere of socialization through MMORPGs, including multiple parallel private chats and even more multitasking with the mail client and an Instagram app, all while playing the game. And it does this pretty well. It made me remember my life back when I used to play WoW a lot.

This game is an idea - an instense idea charged with emotion. It feels very raw and extremely personal. Being allowed to go through her desktop, reading chat logs and looking and sent pictures, felt very intimate. It really plays with one's voyeuristic curiosity. Then there are the voice chats, which again feel like overhearing someone's intimate conversation - full of sighs and hmmm". Nine is a charming and pleasant-sounding person

reviewText:
This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer/publisher.
Cibele is an indie FMV/interactive story title that was released in November 2015, being developed by Star Maid Games. The game is based on a true story, of a girl named Nina, who starts an online “relationship” with a man who she meets whilst playing a game called Valtameri. Those of you who have played online games such as Worlds of Warcraft will probably be able to relate to this game a lot, as there are always those two people in your guild who acted like this.

The gameplay in Cibele is simple. You are a girl who is playing the video game Valtameri. The gameplay in that game is simple, and you have no chance of dying, you simply click to move and attack the enemies, that is it. There is no hidden agenda here; it’s just a method in which the story can progress. You are in a voice call with your friend, Blake, after every so many kills of monsters, the dialogue will progress into the story more. Between each chapter, you get a real life cut scene featuring the two involved. This game should be considered only for mature audience and should not be played when young eyes can see your screen.  Whilst you are in the world of Valtameri, you have other options to explore, such as the instant messenger which adds a little more background and depth to the story. Outside of the game, you can dig around Nina’s computer, reading emails, looking at pictures, reading her blog, etc. This all adds to the immersion of the game allowing you to get into the mind of this young lady.

Whilst the graphics aren’t really a main focal point in Cibele, I did find the art style extremely pleasing to look at, it has a very clean look, and the animations of everything in the game is near enough perfect.  On top of the really nice looking graphics, the game is fully voice acted, in the parts where you would expect it, so the voice chat, using something like TeamSpeak or Ventrilo, it really sounds like you are there with them as you listen. The cut scenes do have any sound effects or voice acting in though, I think this is to add to the effect of the story that things are often different between people when they meet in real life after coming together online. That’s how I took it anyway.

There isn’t any difficulty level here, you will finish the game, and it only takes about an hour to do, and that is with reading blogs, checking out emails etc. I don’t think there would be any replay ability since the story seems pretty linear, so I wouldn’t say it’s worth a second play through.

I did notice a slight stutter/frame drop at times when playing, this appeared to happen when new enemies entered the screen, which I found strange given that my rig is able to handle much more taxing games than this. I was able to play on 1440p though, so all resolutions were tight and crisp.  Keyboard and mouse will be needed to play.

To sum up, Cibele is an interesting title, that can be picked up for £5,99, I for one think that is a fair price for what is on offer, and the high standard of production values that have gone into this game. Some of you may get a nostalgia hit with the story, whilst others may actually enjoy the gameplay of the game in Cibele, but I can certainly say it is worth the full marked up price for an hour’s enjoyment.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Self reflection is weird, and I'd never expect something like this from a game, but I can't wait for more like this.
Being around Nina's age and having very similar experiences to what was portrayed in Cibele, this game was simultaneously a treat and a self reflective crisis straight out of heck. Everything felt very real and I was thrust back into my younger years of roleplaying on forums and hiding away with the people I had crushes on in MMOs as if it was our sacred space. I had almost entirely forgotten some of those days.
I mean sure, now that I'm older and more removed from that insecure teen mindset, some of that stuff embarrassed me because I /knew/ I was exactly like that and it was almost hard to face that head on. It's posting on xanga about those neopets friends you hung out with immediately after school. It's getting the courage to show those friends what you look like and not knowing what to say when they don't bag on you. It's doing the same stuff in maplestory and wondering if you actually learned anything from before. It's being a confused and misguided teen in the mid 2000s and wondering what the hell any of this means.
It didn't feel like sifting through a stranger's computer, it felt like looking through my own old harddrives and talking to my old friends. I put about an hour and a half into this, getting kinda sucked in to the experience and exploring everything I could. Honest to the point that you kinda cringe or squirm cos you know what's happening and just wanna pull both characters aside and just talk to them like a weird mom, I'd recommend this to anyone that drifted through internet love affairs. Learning about love makes you do some silly stuff. Here's to you, tiny me that didn't understand even half the things I do now.

reviewText:
Cibele – Narrative, Autobiography
a spoiler-free review

Release Date: 2 Nov, 2015
Rating: Recommended with Caution

- Overview -
Cibele is a game about online gaming, community, love and the complexities of virtual/real-life relationships. It’s close to being a visual novel or movie, but interestingly enough has what resembles an MMORPG that the player interacts with and plays in. The game starts the player on the PC desktop of the protagonist Nina Freeman. From there you can read her blog files, see selfies, poetry drafts for her university courses or boot Valtameri, the aforementioned MMORPG.

- Story - (spoiler-free)
Nina is a girl that is passionate about many things: anime, photography and gaming among them. Inevitably she is drawn to an online game where she becomes part of a sort of clan, led by a male user by the screenname of Ichi. Nina, under the username Cibele, interacts with the other users and her friends via IM. Voice-acted sound clips progress the plot while the player is destroying monsters online in Valtameri.

- Visuals/Audio -
This game utilizes the modern minimalist art style coupled with soft, ambient synth music. While perhaps not the most original of styles, it is effective in giving the game a strong emotional charge.

- So why the negative rating? –
As you can see by my playtime, I finished this game in just over an hour. I was by no means rushing. The base retail price is $8.99, which is a bit staggering for an hour-long commentary game. If it goes on sale for 90% off, get it. I got it in a Humble Bundle for $1, so I am not complaining by any means, but if games were priced by average hours of enjoyment, this one would be ~900% overpriced.

The story was wonderful and I really enjoyed it, but the ending is dissatisfying, feels somewhat rushed and sorta comes out of nowhere, though it is plausible I guess. All in all, it’s a great archetype for how a story game should be presented and if the developer were to make another piece I would strongly consider buying it.

- Quick Note -
The game is recommended for mature audiences. It deals with topics such as sex and college party life. Some of the content is very suggestive, but nothing heavier than PG-13.

Not Recommended
- Recommended with Caution
Recommended
Highly Recommended
Recommended as Essential

reviewText:
People are calling this game poorly executed. So was the diary I started at the age of 13—and I only need to look at that for a few seconds to feel far more powerful horrified regret than I'd get from hours with the latest roguelike Minecraft/DayZ variant. Similar forces lurk within Cibele.

Let me acknowledge: I follow this author on social media. We've never met, nor (I think) exchanged direct communication. Casual observation suggests that our lives don't intersect. We care about different things, we operate in different ways, and we're moving in different directions.

Cibele made me doubt that dissimilarity: perhaps we're more alike than I thought. Perhaps far more alike. I might believe this because I once occupied a role in a story that echoes the one she tells here, but it might just be that her story hides truth and universality behind its minute details.

Graphics: a photo of your crush / 10
Story: a long blog post you wrote ten years ago / 10
Replayability: your first kiss / 10
Overall: I once made the girl who liked me sit through the Eyes On Me" cutscene from Final Fantasy VIII
date: and I can never undo that / 10\n\nIn conclusion: Cibele is all the voyeuristic truth I craved in adolescence steeped in all the self-reflection I've come to dread as an adult. Highly recommended."

reviewText:
First of all, this is more of a story experience than a game. You probably already know whether you're into things like that.

Secondly, yes, it is short, about the length of a full length motion picture. Other reviewers have commented that this title should be cheaper. You can rent an HD movie on certain streaming platforms for $3-6, so if you think about it that way, this title won't cost much more than that on sale. If you don't have qualms about giving a couple extra bucks to support indie devs who are creating experiences different from the norm, then I think you'll feel okay about paying full price for this title.

The story really hit home for me. I felt like the characters were people I could have known growing up. Actually, I hate to admit it, but I feel like I could have BEEN one of these characters. The long-distance internet relationships, awkward interactions, teenage blog posts, instant messaging 4 different friends at the same time with different moods in each conversation while voice chatting with someone else--the feelings were all very familiar.

Some reviewers have said that the pseudo-MMO aspect isn't engaging enough gameplay-wise. Sure, it's no .hack, but that didn't detract from the experience for me, as it mainly served as a backdrop for the very real and very human interactions between the characters. Thinking of it in contrast to a visual novel rather than an MMO might make more sense.

All told, I recommend it. Your mileage may vary if you want more from a game
date: and the value proposition may not be worth it for those who don't relate to the characters and situations presented, but if any of the situations I described above made you feel a tinge of nostalgia or regret, you might be as touched by this story as I was.

reviewText:
An Interactive Story about Online Dating in Video Gameshttps://youtu.be/T_5_LqZ12fQ
To give some perspetive, the game is based on a true story about a young girl, Nina, who meets someone on an online game (based around Final Fantasy XI), and the relationship and events that unfold over the course of a few months.

+ An incredibly realistic story that many gamers can relate to based around online / long distance dating, and meeting people through video games. I've personally had very similar experiences.
+ I found it to be very interesting to play as the perspective of the female in this game. It was a bit eye opening at how annoying it must be to constantly be flirted with by random jerks online who all seemingly want to sleep with you or get nude pics.
+ Very realistic characters. I was actually thoroughly pleased when the guy had some anxiety issues, and doubts about buying a plane ticket and flying across country to meet the girl for the first time outside the game. To me this is a cautionary tale for girls and guys alike. It's far easier to talk to people online, on the phone, or through games, and when you meet someone in real life you may find that things don't work out as well....which is actually VERY common.
+ Great dialogue, which was incredibly well written and felt very genuine. The flirting especially was very cringe-worthy at times, but it often is when starting relationships as the guy gives the girl a lot of corny yet flattering compliments.
+ I may get some hate for this, but I give this game props for looking into the 	aboo" that is sexting and trading pics. In online environments it's extremely common for relationships to begin by trading pics far before you ever meet someone in real life. I also give props to the developer who shared all of these pictures to the somewhat judgemental gaming community.
+ It almost feels like you are a stalker as you browse through her computer each time looking at her pictures

reviewText:
This is one of those games that will be somewhat meaningful to people depending on what they’ve experienced in their own life and how it lines up with the one being told here.

Me, I have never had this sort of experience before and therefore do not truly understand what is being said to me. If there was a message, it wasn’t for me.

In Cibele, you’re basically looking into someone else’s life with a magnifying glass. For me, it was like I hacked into someone’s Myspace profile. Intruding. Looking for every piece of information available with little reason why. I guess if you were interested in Nina before Cibele, here you go. But for me, I wasn’t even aware of her existence until the internet gaming press decided to praise this game like the gospel.

Anyway, there was also this awkward online relationship being told in Cibele. A story that could have been summed up in a sentence based on the information handed to me. There should have been a lot more. Like, how did this relationship come about in the first place? How did Nina meet him? Who are these other people talking and their relationship to Nina? How did it develop over time? Why didn’t it work out? These sort of questions. Maybe some of Nina’s inner thoughts.

Bring me in deeper, give me more perspective into to this life of yours because playing this game right now just seems like I’m stepping my toe into a pool of water. In other words, it’s shallow. So those even for those looking for some sort of connection isn’t going to get that strong-- of a connection. There’s nothing to see here.

The game Valtameri" isn’t that good of a game either. The character you play as often gets stuck whilst your buddy

reviewText:
The short and reductive version – A slightly more depressing and uncomfortable but interactive version of the YouTube series “The Guild” by Felicia Day.

The slightly more detailed version – You as play the developer of this game or perhaps a character.. maybe some summation of possibly real experiences of the human Nina Freeman. The main interface is that of her desktop. A bit of a homebody, she has a number of online friends mostly gained from the game she plays online. Which I think a lot of people can relate to in the modern world. The game shes plays from what I can surmise is a fairly dull and repetitive MMO; But that game is mostly a vehicle to deliver and give atmosphere to the conversations she has with her friends.

I found myself surprisingly engaged with the conversations she was having. While simultaneously feeling VERY uncomfortable as if I had invaded someones privacy against their will; against MY will. Which I think is by design. I don't want to really say the degree to which these relationships go or how many there are but I think if you've heard anything about this game through the grapevine you can probably guess pretty accurately what happens. However, I think its pretty unique of way of telling this specific story.

I find that these sorts of experimental kind of 'artsy fartsy' games usually overstay their welcome as in; The hook has penetrated, enraptured you and then made you wait to hear its secrets. But this one feels like it 'under'stays its welcome. I feel like it ends a bit abruptly.

The comparison to 'Her Story' is easy but accurate. In all honesty, this tells a different story about something else entirely. After playing both, I like Her Story overall a bit better but because Cibele made me feel uncomfortable that maybe hits a little closer to home than I'd like to admit and in ways that Her Story did not. It is uniquely different.

reviewText:
Overall it's alright for a short game; it's not worth $10.

2 Major Cons:

1. Most of the story you're in a game hack/slashing enemies. You actually get kind of into it -- however it aggrevates the crap out of you because of the horrible pathing and overall clunkiness of the gameplay. It's not the beef of the game - but it should still be enjoyable and effortless to play a little simple game while interacting with everything else happening.

2. The game ends abruptly, however there's a line in the ending that makes you assume there might be more to the story. There isn't. While I'm satisfied with the story, there could definately be a bit of a continuation or more of a look into how the protagonist deals with the ending.

The characters are real and relatable, even the friends you only interact with through IM. The UI is pleasant and tells a lot about the girl's personality. The acting is kind of awkward, but it works for the characters.

If you bought this in the Humble Bundle like I did - it's worth an hour or 2 of playthrough. Not worth the $10 though, considering the only part you actually play is so poorly executed.

Sorry, but, what on earth did I just play?

Cibele is like one of those games you try to like. You try to sort of have an open mind to it because it's from a 'niche' part of the gaming genre in general.

But the game itself? it felt like a B class movie to be quite frank.

Felt like a PSA about people who live online. Kind of actually takes a chunk out of me because it sorta brings a bad rep to people who have relationships online and it refers to, in my opinion, a very small amount of unpleasant people here.

I dont usually want to refund a game but I actually want my 6 Pounds back. Quite a let down considering it was on the supposed 'Games Awards'. It's a great try but it is extremely under developed.

The game has potential. Started of very well but ended very abruptly and was just a very confusing ending rather than a cliffhanger with a meaning behind it. It wasn't even a cliffhanger, just more like a gentle rise with a steep decline.

Sorry developer, gotta try harder next time.

reviewText:
I hate stupid, naive youth. I never was this dumb and innocent, but I think there are loads of people that have gone through this. It was interesting as a male to play through the perspective of a girl and i liked that aspect, but you knew where the story was going and the dialogue gave everything away.

I also really enjoyed the mini movie clips implemented and the computer interaction with different angles of her life. It gave her an almost well-rounded feeling.

I am only not recommending it because, well not because it was short, but it had a loooong build up and a very anti-climactic ending (no pun intended).

It was enjoyable for a bit. Indie-devs are pretty common nowadays and this was a different and interesting take on a real life experience.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I wanted to like Cibele, but it just felt more like a diary entry than a game or even a short film. It's an interesting idea, but It just didn't make for a very compelling experience by the end. I guess I was looking for some interesting twist that was never going to come.

I think the problem was that this story will only really resonate with someone who has been through a similar experience, but if they have, this telling isn't really any more interesting than the experience they've already had. It's sort of a catch-22. It feels (and clearly is) very personal, but personal in kind of a bland way.

I do appreciate the chances Nina Freeman takes with her games, they all feel like potentially fascinating experiments. I just don't think this particular experiment was one of them.

reviewText:
Extremely interesting concept which I hadn't encountered before in any game whatsoever. This game is immersive and short BUT in my opinion it would not appeal to a wide variety of players. I find this heavily aimed at young female gamers to encourage reminiscence and self reflecton which it achieved beautifully. The focus on this game is based HEAVILY on Nina's relationships and is not based on immersive shoot em' up gameplay, so before you buy this game .. please take that into consideration.

The reality of this is pretty surreal and I have come accross countless online relationships like this and so to play a game based on that idea created a very interesting experience.
I would recommend this to all female gamers who may have encountered a similiar situation and all others with an open mind. Do not expect to shoot things, complete puzzles ect. Enter the game with an open mind and you will be submersed into the reality of Nina's life.

reviewText:
A few things before I begin; I would describe my experience with this game as negative but it is my hope that Cibele will have a positive impact on the medium of video games. A review marked as 'negative' probably wouldn't help this game reach any kind of success, so for the sake of trying to be helpful I'll settle with the blue thumb. I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone I didn't know personally or anyone at all really.

I don't feel great recommending anything to anyone but I can confidently say that if you don't see any value in games as an artform then there's probably nothing here for you. If you do however, you might derive some enjoying in seeing what Cibele has to offer. Whether or not you'll walk away from it positively or negatively is unknown to me.

-

Cibele follows the age old rule of three rather strictly;  there are three different sections of gameplay, the story is told in three different acts and the bosses go down after the third time you fight them.

The first of these is the virtual desktop of Nina, the protagonist. It's littered with folders filled with various pictures and documents of a personal nature. I often felt a sense of voyeurism, and sometimes dread, looking through Nina's files. The content isn't graphic or even scandalous. Quite the opposite actually. It's a mix of selfies, poetry, photography, chat logs and archives of old blog posts. Some might call it cringy" but this isn't where my problems lie. My issues stem from those last two items
date: the chatlogs and blog posts. The awkward ramblings of a teenage girl resonate with me more than I'd like to assume. I'm not one to look back fondly on the things I've said
recommended:
made or done. Seeing bits of myself and the way I used to think and express myself online in these files brought on a feeling that most would describe as disgust. I didn't like looking at them.

These do not need to be opened or looked at to progress but they provide a nice amount of context to the kind of person Nina is and was. These files also fill in the gaps between the time skips that occur throughout the story.

The second third is the ♥♥♥♥♥♥me-within-a-game you play called Valtameri. It's definitely the most "game-y" of the three parts of Cibele and
hoursPlayed: unfortunately
voteText: it isn't very good. But that's not the purpose of it. Valtameri is an almost insulting distillation of what ♥♥♥♥♥♥meplay eventually becomes
helpfulPercent: a means to socialize with other people. A virtual space to hangout in. Valtameri is a crude facsimile of one half of the MMO experience
votesHelpful: actually playing the game. Its actually kind of hard to believe that anyone could enjoy actually playing this game due to it's lack of depth or substance.\n\nIt does convey its point rather effectively though. It's the method by which Nina and her object of desire
votesTotal: Blake
votesFunny: interact and speak to each other through. These portions mostly focus on the social aspect of MMOs as the true focus is not the game but the conversations being had
commentsCount: both text and actual voiced dialogue. It's an aspect of these kinds of games I'm turned off by. I played over 50 hours of TERA recently on the least populated server in an attempt to isolate myself from anyone else who might be playing. There was once a time when I embraced and enjoyed the social features of an MMO and the idle chatter in these portions felt oh so familiar. These are fond memories mind you
column16: but I experienced them with people whose names I hardly remember. I don't really like thinking about these sorts of things.\n\nThe third and final side of Cibele are the FMV cutscenes. Most of them are short
column17:
interstitial videos that bridge the gap between acts but there are a couple of longer scenes that add to the story. They do a good enough job of establishing the mood and vibe in the moments following and preceding the acts. The quality is a bit... poor but I think they're shot and framed rather well.

At this point I hope I've made it clear that I didn't have a great time with Cibele. Most of this negativity is from my own personal experiences and how I view them now. Obviously your mileage may vary for a lot of the content but even in the case of the things Cibele does that you can look at objectively I have a hard time justifying them as anything other than decent at best.

Despite my distaste for it
column18: I can recognize and appreciate the risks it takes. The autobiographical nature of the story is something that is not often seen in games. When it is
column19: it's usually in games that are available for free and distributed by more personal means. The fact that Cibele is something you can buy with actual money on a rather large distribution platform with such high visibility fills me with a bit of hope. A hope that games of such a personal nature can reach an audience and experience some modicum of success and a hope that it will eventually inspire someone to create something greater. I don't like this game very much but I'm very glad it exists."

reviewText:
Here is a strange thing about attraction: Sometimes, you only like a person enough to sleep with them exactly once.

The strange and sad thing is that sometimes you have no idea who these people will be until you actually do it.

But, then again: Sometimes, you do.

The difficult part is that, when you're betrayed by somebody this way, they're always going to claim - even unspokenly - to have been the former rather than the latter.

And only you can decide how you want to carry that: How much you believe them, how much you care yourself, how much you want to think of it as a part of growing up, or how much you can accept that looking back on ♥♥♥♥♥♥ things with a certain amount of fondness is weird and strange and true.

Cibele is really short. There isn't much to it. But saying much more would probably mean saying less.

reviewText:
Cibele is a very unusual indie game that focuses on online relationships and bringing them to the real world.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

Please note: I rarely put a warning like this into my reviews, but this is something that you have to know when reading my review: this is not a game for everyone. You can see many reviews on Steam with contradictory opinions. This game does not offer what you would expect from a normal video game. Before buying the game, do yourself a favour and decide if this is your cup of tea.
What is happening in the game:You are a 19 year old girl who is playing a video game called Valtameri on a daily basis. One there, you are chatting with a guy that becomes attracted to you (and you to him). As you get more and more involved with him, you want to meet him in person and start pushing your real life friends away from you.

Pros:    Story and Voice Acting | Despite the ending (see Cons), I have to say that I enjoyed Cibele's story quite a lot! Of course, it doesn't have the greatest budget and a ton of skilled writers behind it, but it still touches one's heart for a short while. The voice acting is more convincing that some people say it is - when the other guy says he loves you, his voice is not what you would call the most confident, but, as you reveal in the third act, his voice actually has good reasons to be that way. I'm not sure all people understood the point of the game (as said before, this game is not for everyone).
In-game Game | This is another thing a lot of people misunderstood - the game your are playing in Cibele is not supposed to be the main thing in the whole gameplay. It's merely an environment where Nina and Blake are communicating and opening to each other. That thing with moving around and killing monsters is built in so you would actually do something while listening to the story. I mean, do you want to stare at the same screen for one hour while the story is unfolding? I don't think so.
The Soundtrack | The soundtrack is pretty nice as well, it's not very intrusive and it adds a nice layer to the whole gameplay. You can also buy it as a DLC here.
Graphics | The desktop, the pictures, the Valtameri game, they all look super nice. Recorded footage looks nice as well.
Depth of the Gameplay | This is one of the games that has optional" content. In each one of the acts
date: there is a different desktop with different folders
hoursPlayed: e-mails and pictures. In other words

votesHelpful: there is a sudden and unexpected twist that is at the same time the end of the game. I was expecting something more emotional or at least conclusive.\nGameplay Time vs. Price | For a bit over one hour of gameplay

reviewText:
Firstly, I don't think £6 is a reasonable price for something that is essentially a short film with perfunctory interactive segments, especially when the expected playtime was 1.5 to 2 hours and it took me just over an hour to play the game. That said, I received Cibele as part of the narrative Humble Bundle, so I feel like it was worth it whatever segment of the price went to it in that context.

I did, however, enjoy the story, even if I found the acting a little lacking at times. I especially enjoyed the look and feel of the MMORPG! I'm not sure whether it was my computer or intentionally designed that way, but certain parts of the boss fights were laggy, and that definitely upped the realism of it. :'D

I'm aware that the story is purely about Nina and her first love with a guy she meets online, but I would have loved a little more focus on the periphary characters and the relationships Nina had with them and how her relationship with Blake had affected that. You get an idea of what's happening, but I would have just liked more, you know? Plus I feel like the game could have used a follow-up act, but that might just be me.

Overall, I don't have negative feelings about Cibele--I enjoyed my time experiencing it--but I'm not sure I can recommend it at the Steam retail price based on what the product is itself; I don't think there's £6 worth of pay-off here.

reviewText: Somewhat interesting at the beginning, but quickly turns into a contrived juvenile narrarative  about a socially awkward teenage girl who is manipulated and used for sex, but can't put it together. And so the story ends with a bleeding heart comment about first love, leaving you as the player to surmise that this story will inevitably resurface years later via some therapy session or another after another poor life decision directly resulting from her naivete and complete lack of awareness about the real world.\n\nMaybe I'm being a big cynical here, but I guess I'm not exactly the target audience for this game...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
What I expected to be a heartfelt and introspective look at relationships, on par with Digital: A Love Story, turned out to be a poorly written, overly simplistic and angsty tale that bordered on fan-fiction, which, given the context of the story, It very well may have begun as.

The 'gameplay' segments are absurdly simplistic with next to no polish, to the extent that they could be replicated in Scratch with very little difficulty. The 'Fully interactive desktop' that the game description touts is, in actuality, nothing more than completely banal text documents which reveal almost to no information about anything relative to the story. The epitome of meaningless side content.

The short film segments that bookend each 'chapter' sway between being boring and uninteresting (although admittedly they are at least relatively well shot) and being cringeworthy in their portrayals of budding romance between adults.

If there is one thing, however, that I could say this game has going for it, it would be the voice acting in the calls between the main character and her prospective lover. Overall they gave a somewhat believable performance that made me smile a couple of times.

Basically, this 'game' is someones final term project, wrapped up and put on steam for profit. I assume. If this is the case then fair enough it is an impressive effort for a student project but as a professional effort it falls short in too many ways to count.

Do yourself a favour and save the £6 for something competent.

2/10 - Glad I got this in a bundle

The acting is bad, the dialogue is repetitive, boring and badly mashed together. It often stops entirely to let you reach the end of the painfully boring and glitchy MMO minigame and progress the chapter onwards.

Feels like a first year university project.

Play Her Story" instead."

reviewText:
Nina Freeman is no stranger to the creation of short games that explore sexual topics, and Cibele doesn’t stray far from her current curriculum vitae. She plays the role of her 19-year-old-self in Cibele, a Steam game based on a true story that unfolds across three mediums: click-based gameplay, audio conversations, and video intermissions.

The game aims to relive the moments of a first love, sparked between Nina (who goes by the online name of Cibele) and another player named Ichi. Players will dive into Nina’s life at the time, exploring her computer files, old photos, and interacting with Ichi through an in-game MMORPG called Valtameri, which is loosely based on Final Fantasy Online.

The game jumps between clicking through an interactive computer, audio conversations during bouts of Valtameri, and real-life video cutscenes (which is where the game garners its mature recommendation). Cibele cycles between all three mediums repetitively as the story unfolds throughout three seperate acts, which span several months in 2009. The mesh of mediums doesn’t always work, however, and we were left feeling that Cibele could have been a better story hadn’t tried to cross streams between separate video only, audio only, and click-based content, which each come into focus at separate times.

It quickly becomes apparent that Cibele is much less of a game than it is an interactive film, and its worst parts are when it forces players to attempt the in-game MMORPG, Valtameri. As Cibele plays with Ichi, the characters are expected to go and defeat a bunch of grind-based enemies to lure out a final boss, with players following the same template over all three acts that Cibele brings to the table.

Cibele is what poets would call confessional, focused on dreadfully intimate revelations and discussing the kinds of truths that rarely come up in polite conversation. One of the first things you have the opportunity to do is look at Nina’s selfies. Some of them are meant for public consumption. Some of them are definitely not. The rest of the game is made up of equally private ephemera: late-night online conversations, chat logs, unfinished blog posts. Together, they paint a personal portrait of their creator, her sexuality, and some of her most dearly held formative experiences.

One of the reasons why confessional storytelling is so rare in games might be because of the way it puts a lie to one of our most commonly held assumptions about players and the characters they control. We generally imagine that, when you play as someone, you are becoming them—adventuring as Lara Croft, saving the human race as the Master Chief, etc., etc. Confessional narratives shatter that illusion with experiences so specific and so tied to their creator that the distance between the player and the character is always present. When we see Freeman’s pictures and hear her voice, her personhood is inescapable. You may occupy her world—role-playing as her in Valtameri, sitting in her chair at her computer—but you never become her. Instead, you exist in a between space, both inside and outside, not her but not separate, either.

This is a game about that drive to connect, to see others and yourself clearly. It’s an experiment in how a creator might put themselves into a work and make a game that speaks honestly about their real life to the people who play it. Through Freeman’s relationship with Ichi, it also illustrates how the distance between people shapes the way they understand each other, and how collapsing that distance can be a profound risk. It’s the same risk that permeates a project like Cibele, both in the creation and the playing. In sharing so much, with a friend or a lover or an audience, you give up just as much control. What if they don’t like what they see?

Most of you may whine about the ending of the game, like I did, I admit, that there's no punchline,its like the arc is missing and left unaddressed. It feels like someone yelled, Cut!" too soon.And this has become my favourite part of this visual novel right after i slept on it. The actual punchline of the game is its cult reality

recommended: but as all we know that life isn't a fantasy

reviewText: I REALLY, REALLY want to like this. I heard about it because Nina worked for KillScreen, one of the best gaming publications out there right now, in my opinion. The concept is fascinating, brilliant even: through voice-over, you hear the story of a 19 year old girl meeting and falling for a guy in her MMO collective. It's some kinda crappy Ragnarok-type clone, and the VASTLY interesting part is their voice-over.\n\nThe real problem is that the game that you are forced to play to advance the story honestly isn't a game at all. It's just hundreds, thousands, of meaningless clicks. There's no way to lose, no choices to make, no weapons to change out, no HP or MP meters to watch, no variation in enemies, no varariation in level design, no variation in bosses." You're forced to watch the same repetitive animations over and over with absolutely no impact on the outcome

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥ THIS GAME!
After playing things like Emily is Away I expected so much of this game.
You enter the game and you get put in the desktop, like in Emily is Away. Everything's confusing and the hitboxes for the folders and stuff are still a mystery to me. I still don't know how to open a file/folder. The pictures inside are just small and you can't even enlarge it, so they just mean nothing to you, seeing as there's no real context of the photo and they feel like a mess of pixels.
It's time to start the game. First of all, the game looks ugly as hell, seriously ugly. Cibele, the avatar is in an MMO dungeon, but the pathfinding sucks and the gameplay is just grindy and boring. The enemies don't attack you. At the same time your raid partner has a character that can fly over obstacles and will teleport in a way, so he'll appear in front of you. I would love doing that, but no, I can't. The game also runs like ♥♥♥♥. I had a solid 15fps the whole way through, even though it is simple and it looks horrible. It's just a freaking mess. The optimization is so bad in the game that they even pretend that you need 4GB of RAM, even though games with similar caliber will run with 512MB - 1GB of RAM. But, this one thinks it's a special game.
The video parts. They are ridiculous. At one point in the game *SPOILERS* ~there's a sex scene~. But it's awkward as ♥♥♥♥ to watch. They have no chemistry and the cameraman just pervs at the woman, you can even see his shadow. It's ♥♥♥♥ing awful is what it is. Also, I need to mention how many upskirt shots there are. It's just creepy.
The voice acting is ok on the guy's part (can't even remember the name, that's how bad it was), but Cibele sounds so fake and thanks to that all I can think is that she's a spoiled little daddy's girl that needs to be validated every other minute and how she feels like a manipulative cow. The guy is a better voice actor, but still sounds like a massive brat, while saying You talked to your friends?! LAME!" and ♥♥♥♥ like that.
And now

reviewText: I'm just a few years older then Nina, so the timing of the technology and some of the experiences are not that far off from my own. It's a very strange place to revisit that place in time, and exploring the web posts, photos, chat logs—it brings so much back.\n\nThis isn't a game for players looking for mechanics and levels and that kind of thing—this game is about putting yourself in the perspective of a person navigating relationships online and off, during a particular time in the history of the internet. For some, it will resonate very closely, depending on their own experiences. I can't say that it was a particularly strong or moving experience for me, but it does provoke some interesting reflections on what my attitudes and expectations once were, a decade-and-a-half ago.

reviewText:
I absolutely love it when videogames are used to tell very small and personal stories, so I knew I would enjoy Cibele before I even played it. Feel free to consider me biased. As the game’s official description on steam puts it, “Cibele is a game about love, sex, and the internet. You play as a 19 year old girl who has become close with a young man she met in an online game.” The game consists of 3 chapters, all of which alternate between the protagonist’s desktop, the MMO she plays, and, finally, the live action sequences.

The desktop part is a neat, albeit at times an uncomfortably voyeuristic experience. You get to browse through Nina’s blogs, e-mails, poems, and random notes. As someone who is fascinated by people’s rooms/apartments and what they tell about a person who lives there, learning about a person from the contents of their desktop felt equally as cool to me.

The MMO portion is a rather simple point and click ordeal. I’ve seen people criticise the blandness of the in-game MMO’s gameplay, but I feel that is kind of the point. Cibele definitely invoked some MMO-related nostalgia for me. I don’t remember grinding being that much fun (and there was a lot of grinding) back when I played WoW 5-10 years ago. So in order to make it more bearable I would alt tab and look at Wowhead, IM people, browse forums etc etc etc, all the while playing WoW. I feel like Cibele captured that feeling perfectly. It’s not necessarily about the game itself, it’s about everything that happens around it. The experience of being a part of something felt much more important than the experience of killing random skeletons.

I was a little cautious about the live action scenes at first, due to the fact that Nina Freeman, who plays herself, is not a professional actor. But these parts never outstay their welcome either. All of them are very brief and to the point. Even the last live action portion of the game, which has much more weight to it than the previous two, is executed quite well and never feels out of place in the context of a game.

Cibele is not a game for everyone, but that should be obvious from the game’s description as well as its trailer. I think that Nina Freeman and her Star Maid Games have created a special little gem of a game, which I’m sure that I will come back to sooner or later. If you feel like spending an hour in somebody’s shoes so that you can experience a formative, if not a very pleasant, time in their life, then Cibele is well worth your time and money.

reviewText:
I've never both loved and resented a game this much for a long time.

Cibele puts you centre stage of Nina's life a teenager whose formed a relationship with someones shes met online. I adored Nina, I could identify completely with her character and the motions she went through falling for someone she's never met. Ofcourse she felt real and tangible, from the cute anime fan art to the debating which selfie to send. People are far too quick to throw these things into the categories 'vain' and 'empty-headed' when in reality thats what being a teenager is all about.

The story itself was cute and well structured, but the ending fizzled out before it felt as though it had even began. It was dissapointing to not find any resolve or explanation, it made sense but it also didn't offer anything to truly think about.

The gameplay is a whole other story, the sections of browsing Nina's PC where fun and did help pad out the story but the tedious yet beautiful MMO sections where insufferable. There's nothing worse than just having to aimlessly click in order to push forward a story. I felt slightly cheated as the screenshots seemed to offer a level of interactivity that the actual game didn't actually have. Your character is also terrible at following paths as you mindlessly try and click to attack an onscreen monster.

I wouldnt reccomend this game to anyone but I would love to see Nina's future projects and take onboard what people have said, there is a lot of potential!

reviewText: Cibele is a love story told through a mixture of MMO voice chat, FMV, photos, and blog posts. The 'game' sequences are just there to provide a context for the voice chat, so the effect is something like a biographical short film or a kinetic visual novel. There are a few minor UI issues (e.g. pathfinding in the MMO sequences) but overall it hangs together really well. I found the story really interesting because it was so alien to my experience as an MMO-hating dude rapidly approaching 40. The kids these days with their internet romance and their 'lol', I dunno! It's a short experience (about an hour), but the length felt appropriate to me. If you like Christine Love games you will probably dig this.

reviewText:
I want to preface this by saying that I'm glad games like this exist. I'm a big fan of projects like Gone Home, Dear Esther, The Stanley Parable and similar games. That being said, I think Cibele crosses the line past game and more into film or something else entirely.

There really is almost no gameplay to speak of here at all. The game is split between time file surfing on Nina's desktop and playing the online game with Ichi. Each time you play the game, you click on enemies which kills them and eventually, a boss comes. Rinse and repeat a few times and the boss dies and you move to the next act. Even this small amount of gameplay was frustrating as the character often couldn't make her way around corners and I'd have to maneuver her to find more enemies to click on. It's a small gripe but considering that it is literally the entire game, it stands out quite a bit.

That's really not the reason to come to this game though, anyway. The focus is really on the storyline, an online first love between Nina and Ichi. While I'm positive that this will resonate with some folks, it just didn't with me. To go more into detail would inevitably spoil the experience but if you're older than about 18, the story goes exactly how you'd expect with the actors providing decent, if not stellar, performances.

It's hard to say more about this game. It's easily completeable within two hours (my playthrough lasted 89 minutes) so if the premise sounds really interesting and you're looking for a short experience, maybe this will be for you. Based on my experience though, I just can't justify a recommendation to most players.

reviewText: Nina is an incredibly honest person, and I appreciate seeing that come through in her games. I'm a big fan of some of her other games (such as Freshman Year) because these games are about topics usually ignored in games. Cibele focuses on relationships over the internet -- mostly romantic, but also platonic! The game reflects a lot of my own experiences, and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a short story about games, the internet, and perfectly awkward flirting.

reviewText: Unnervingly intimate look at relationships that I got emotionally invested in. I have to scratch my head as to whether there are other games that dive into relationships this well, other than visual novels or the unintentionally hilarious Facade. Much like A Beginner's Guide, it's like a playable mockumentary where you're in a game within a game and like Her Story, it uses live action FMV and a computer desktop as the aesthetic. While playing the in-fiction MMO is not exactly thrilling and quite repetitive (maybe that's the point!), juggling between texts, messages, diaries, while clicking on an enemy intermittently replicates the feel of being social while playing real MMOs. The relationship itself is believable, which is thanks to this being quite autobiographical on Nina Freeman's part, where what's real and what's made up for recreation purposes gives it that voyerustic intimate vibe. It's just an hour or so long, and it's quite bittersweet overall so left an impact on my mind since I finished it.

reviewText: OMG this game is not great. Or maybe it\'s just not for me. It\'s almost literally a girl\'s journal in interactive form, detailing the time a guy lied and tried to use her for a one night stand. So she made a game about it. Not that it\'s a bad story, just an unremarkable one. Tragically common. Horrifyingly predictable. It\'s quite unfortunate that this story exists. But it\'s also nothing to get really worked up over, unless you are the protagonist. And we\'re kept from \being\" the protagonist of this game. Our actions
hoursPlayed: all predetermined. Which is fine

reviewText:
Wow. WTF did I just play. In short, don't bother.

[MILD SPOILERS]

There is no game here as there's no actual choices being made. You 'play' as Nina, who has never had a boyfriend and never had sex who falls for someone on an MMORPG who has also never had a girlfriend and never had sex. You basically listen to them VOIP and watch a few short movies. The game is over within an hour. There was no way to change any outcomes and the 'game' that you're forced to play was a grind (and not in an ironic MMORPG way). I would have TK'ed him if the server rules allowed it.

Super indie, super boring, super quick and for US$8.99 full price (though I snagged it for US$1 in the humble bundle) it is way overpriced.

I could be harsher though I'm holding myself back here.

reviewText:
I clicked around the desktop after the little intro video. OK I'm clicking around stuff, folders, opening subfolders, viewing pictures. The interface is very intuitive because it's kind of like Windows, kind of like a Mac. There are poetry texts that might be OK but its not like mindblowing... and thats cool because it all creates this very complete four dimensional picture of the protaganist. Nina Freeman is a genius - she has delivered quantum gaming without requiring an oculus. The three dimensions we are all used to in gaming are transcended by this rarely accessed 4th dimension, something superphysical which touches us on a plane that cannot be quantified or examined fully through physical means.

So I'm clicking around and lo and behold I learn about Cibele in 4 dimensions:
1: Cibele is hot. The pink hair and curves are righteous, shes bad. She plays video games, writes poetry, posesses a beautiful voice full of soul. Nina Freeman is simply beautiful, inside and out.
2: Cibele is an especially bright and expressive member of her generation.
3: Cibele has white people/first world problems. Basically her life is going so smoothly, she kind of has to insert sticks into the spokes of her tires in order to give it some texture and meaning.
4: Like a lot of incredible women, Cibele's got a pet turd in her life: Ichi, this mildew ridden lump of a token male love interest.

Its by far the best point and click adventure/storytelling game I have played in a long time. I also enjoyed Emily is Away, a similar game in a similar vein but the production values of Cibele blow it away. And to be fair, compared to the production values of say.... GTA V, Cibele is a pissant minigame played on Michael's iFruit.

What I don't like about Cibele:
1: Super short, I wish it lasted longer because I enjoyed playing this game. Please expand upon the concept and release Manic Pixie Dreamgirl Simulator 2017. However, I basically robbed the devs by acquiring this through Humble Bundle so if you get this on Humble Bundle you just made a very rewarding purchase. As much as I enjoy this game I couldn't really recommend spending more than $5 to buy this game. I am a frugal man, not some fat cat and I didn't acquire my current fortune of many lentils by spending $10 on games that only offer 1-2 hours of entertainment value.

2: You spend most of your time in a fake game within a game" but its kind of like a real game except it has incredibly shallow gameplay because its just a vehicle for carrying the story. There is a fake MMORPG section that you have to play to advance the game which offers gameplay so one dimensional and bug ridden that it does end up detracting from the over all polish and execution of the project. It's tolerable to get to the next bits of story and the little game IMS are a nice storytelling device.

3: The ending feels rushed. There is a slow build most of the game and you get used to the subtleties but the end of the game doesn't match that flow and it's a bit jarring and clumsy kind of like the acting of Nina Freeman's boyfriend "Ichi". (Yeah thats a passive aggresive diss at the designers boyfriend who probably has never been ready for Nina's jelly).

4: I didn't get to see Nina Freeman's boobs outside of their fabric prisons. I'll admit that during the long third "MMORPG Session" in fake game loserville
date: the only thing that kept me clicking forward through the third fake bosses giant life bar was the thought of cool game designing ideal woman nipples. Though she is generous
recommended:
she doesn't give away the farm. Probably smart of her.

I played this game for about an hour or so the first night after purchasing it. It got late and I needed to get to sleep to go to work but I didnt want to lose the feeling of the game so I just switched my monitor off and went to bed. Many hours later I come home from work and light up a joint and switch on my monitor to maybe play some Rocket League. My normal Rain Meter interface and Frank Miller's Wolverine covered wallpaper does not appear but there is a strange linux distro and a fanknockoff sailor moon background. I reach around to the back of my computer to check for a USB running a live OS. My cannabis is very potent and so is this games attention to detail so it took me about 30 seconds of noggin scratchins to alt tab and remember that I had purchased a manic pixie dream girl simulator the night before and left it running for most of a day. I immediately sat down and devoured the rest of Cibeles poignant four dimensional gameplay.

Star Maid

reviewText:
Now before you buy this game... Don't buy it at full price. It's just not worth it.
But does that mean it's a bad game? Definitely not.

This story rich and narrative driven short game is about a real story of an online relationship.
While the dialogue may seem cringy to the player, it's really relatable and not just the characters but the entire game feel very real.
That being said, the game definitely isn't for anyone.

I do however feel as if it should have been more of a typical 5 act drama rather than a 3 act one. The ending is just way to abrupt and I feel like it does not capture emotions sufficiently.

I did find it to be an enjoyable experience during my playthrough. But I wasn't expecting an action rich, feature rich title that would keep me busy for hours anyway. This game will have it's place as one of the more interesting pieces of interactive art and a very important personal object for the developer(s).

reviewText: It is short, and the narrative arc is very much like that of a short story - which may be a bit too abrubt for some people.  But as an expose in online intimacy and innocence the story is still one worth experiencing.  The interactive story mechanics are a little clunky, but the uniqueness of the subject matter still make this a worthy indie experience.  Ultimately the gaming art form is furthered by the existance of this piece of work.  As a two hour experience it is worth your time if you're curious.

reviewText:
If there was an option to chose neutral instead of positive, I would. This isn't technically a game (It has no fail state) it's more of an experimental slice of life project for a very specific kind of person. If you see yourself at all in the trailers or screenshots, Set aside an hour and give it a shot.

If you're skeptical, Know that Cibele completely fails as a ''Game'', But not everything needs to fit that box. The ''Gameplay'' Boils down to looking at private files/Messages and clicking on monsters while listening to two people talk. I think you already know if you're going to enjoy it.

The trailers show Cibele off perfectly. What you see is what you get.  Whether or not it's for you is for you to decide, But I wouldn't take a risk at full price.

Final Rating: 5/10

reviewText: Cibele is a hard game to describe and a harder one to review or recommend. It's not so much of a game than an interactive narrative experience. If you're looking for something like a role-playing game or a dating sim, you're going to be disappointed. If anything, this is more like an indie drama film with buttons. I guess the best way to understand it is to first understand where the developer is coming from. Nina Freeman is known mostly for making autobiographical vignette games. She's more focused on painting a portrait of the characters she portrays than a traditional gaming" experience.\n\nThe game is about Nina
date: a college student who spends most of her time online playing an MMO called Valtameri. She goes on runs with her friend Blake
recommended: who goes by "Ichi" online. Their avatars (who adorably look like Samus from Metroid and Pearl from Steven Universe) grind against mobs until they defeat the boss of each map. During the experience
hoursPlayed: however
voteText: you are given an extremely intimate look into her life. You're allowed to browse her computer as she would
helpfulPercent: looking through her messages and personal photos. While you're online
votesHelpful: you're treated to long voice chats with Blake
votesTotal: and you get to watch how their relationship develops.\n\nIt's really easy to see why this game has a hard time finding its audience. The "gameplay" is extremely limited; you don't really have a choice in any of the interaction you have with Blake. You kind of just watch and wait to see what happens. There isn't even really combat (maybe this is a nod to how boring MMOs can be). Clicking on an enemy auto-attacks it until it dies. The rest of the time
votesFunny: you're kind of just waiting for message replies to move the plot forward.\n\nI think most of the people who've played this game feel like she's taking a stance on what love is/should be. I've read many comments on how "it's her fault for trusting him" or that "she's stupid for falling in love" and other similar sentiments. I've even seen ideas that she's spreading some "Social Justice Warrior" or "feminist" propaganda
commentsCount: but I really doubt that's the idea here. I think this is just exactly what it shows on the surface: it's an honest retelling of Nina's first love and heartbreak. That's it. There's no heroes or villains
column16: it's just two awkward people who've never been in relationships and have a go at it.\n\nIf I were to choose one thing I love about the game
column17: it's the aesthetic design choices. Everything is drawn incredibly cute
column18: and the photos and poems shared feel deeply personal. It's almost perverse how closely you're able to observe Nina's life
column19: and honestly
column20: it kind of made me feel uncomfortable

column22: though

column24: but felt tedious and slow-paced. There's not much to distract you while you're waiting for Nina and Blake's story to develop. Most of their performances are played through audio
column25: so you're not getting much visual feedback other than clicking on little monsters or checking her messages. I doubt many people will want to play it more than once. It's a consumable experience that's heartfelt
column26: but can't leave more of a lasting impression than a movie can. If you like it when games can be replayable over and over again

That piece of knowledge spares you from dissapointment and also helps you make the right choice.\n\nThere's no playing here. It's like living (spying) someone else's life for a couple of hours. You get to check Nina's computer
date: her mails and photos. You can also read her poems and check her website backups
recommended: her posts... All of that helps you understand this 19 year old girl. Then you click on the game's icon and click around making her avatar play the game as you get deeper in her story. reviewText:
I think I should keep this review short... just like the game. Zing!

Cibele is a really short game (it took me right around 1h to finish it) about online relationships of its author. Narrative was also the mane focus for the developers, because the actual gameplay is really minimalistic and clunky, which technically is a bad thing but at the same time isn't a big deal since you only should be getting this if it's narrative seams interesting to you.

I think it's also important to note that the story isn't by no means revolutionary or the best thing that has ever happened to gaming. It's good. But that's about it. The performances of both actors... I wouldn't call them bad. They are good enough. I know that for some people that might not be enough especially at full price, but that's why we have sales and other games.

It's a good Let's get this once it's on a sale" game."

reviewText:
I don't know if I like this game or not, the main reason why is because how abrubt the ending was. It ends very quickly - I understand that the story is based on true life events that happen to the main charecter Nina but, when you create something as a book, movie or a game, you have to embeleshment a little bit you know? I feel like the hole story wasn't properly explored and that's a shame because I trully belive that this game could be something really cool and unique if they tried to explore more the main story and put some thought into, like awesome artwork and a great soundtrack (I missed a tune when exploring desktop, that silence with just the clicking noises was kinda annoying).

The mmo they were playing is really BORING, oh my god, so boring and random... Most of the time you just read messages, and thats ok, I understand thats why that scene exists, it's part of the story  and it's to progress the narrative, it completes the hole story between the two, but I would apappreciate if it was just a looping video or something playing in the background while the player (me) is reading the messages. If it's supposed to actually play or interact with the actual game they are playing, once again, this should be properly explored, like the sensitivity of the mouse was really annoying too, too slow and got into my nerves I must say.

Despite all that, I think I enjoyed play it but It's not worth 10$, I bought it in a bundle with 2 more games for 1$ and that's worth it, so if you find a bundle or smt like that go for it and give it a try!

Would not recommend

Play it!

I will state my points in two folds. One of the common people and one for the developers. If they care that is.

For the common folks. I got this through Humble bundle which are usually a great steal. That being said, I hate to be rude to developers but this game is not worth the amount they ask for. Allow me to expand upon this. 1.5 - 2 hours of gameplay" is really just few clicks here and there with a well illustrated ♥♥♥♥♥♥meplay with very boring mechanics. There is lack of decision-making and most just a linear story. Yes I am aware most games possess this trait as well yet most games I have experienced often provide more then just a click and kill mechanic as well more indepth system that keeps you going. This game does not. If this had options to choose particular paths and had branching endings. I would reconsider stating the cost being worth it or not. Music was sub-par but not bad that one couldn't appreciate it.

For the developer. Please reconsider your approach to this concept of a game. This "game" barks to me as a proof of concept. While I felt like this was more of a PSA type of message. I wish the contents of the game didn't make me want to cringe in the inside. The male lead and the way he talked to the female lead. Ugh. Just utter disgust I felt inside. If this was your intention. reviewText:
Back in my sophomore year of college (exactly one year before I became a drugged-out party ghoul) I met a girl named Kat on Gaia Online. The details of that relationship aren't worth repeating here, but I will say this - we eventually decided to meet, and shortly thereafter everything came apart. We never spoke again.

Maybe it's the curse of being an indoors kid, but I feel like a lot of my friends have had similar experiences. We grew up with helicopter parents and 24 hours scare news, surrounded by a world that seemed safer behind the murky shield of MySpace profile formatting and avatar vanity items. We weren't normal. We weren't cool. We lived small lives that were always under threat of attack from those who played sports or dated - hallmarks of an unnatainable normalcy that haunted us like 17th century poltergeists. We weren't and couldn't be like anyone else. And it hurt.

Then you meet someone online. Someone like you. They play all the same games and watch all the same anime and get all the same references and for the first time you feel something that just begins to resemble that contentment you never really had. The game doesn't even matter. WoW, Gaia, FFO, Neopets - whatever it was you were probably good at it and never really sweated the encounters (if there were any). You weren't really even there for the game. You were there for the people, eventually the person. Maybe you even reached out. Maybe you decided that, if you only met, you could fill that gnawing emptiness with love. That you wouldn't be alone.

But we were young. We hurt each other because we didn't know we could. In the end the the crippling awkwardness and failure of those relationships will color our outlooks for the rest of our lives, because they meant so much more than we ever believed possible. The figures and screen names will fade with time, ghosts in an infernal machine.

That is the story of Cibele. A girl, a boy, the lives they lead and the game they play. It was me. It was Kat. It was everyone who ever stared into a computer screen and believed that love was some untamable primordia that really could conquer all, only to be crushed and left to learn from the things they had said and done. Played out through short film, a mini-RPG and teenage detritus, it is everything we used to be, and everything we are.

And it will break your god damn heart.

reviewText:
This was heartbreaking and wonderous all at the same time. This game was autobiographical, but (if you've ever had an online relationship) it can bring you back to your own past. I felt such a connection to Nina and I will probably replay this. This game may or may not be the game for you, but take a look at the pros and cons and decide if it is something you want to try. Maybe you'll like it more than you think.

Pros:
-Connection to the main character
-Choosing whether or not to reply to the chat box in game
-A peek into the life of Nina through her computer
-Videos letting you see more of Nina's life in addition to her computer files

Cons:
-Actual gameplay in the online game the protagonist plays (cannot move along the story until finished)
-The level of inimacy of looking on someone's computer is almost too much to bear for me. Too many emotions as well as personal things that, if it was my computer, I'd never want anyone to see. (But maybe it's fine since she did include them in the game.)
-A lot of video (I liked it but there was not much actual gameplay.)
-What is happening to Nina now?

Spoilers follow:
This brought me back to my own past online relationships so much. When Blake said he didn't deal well with people irl, I remember my ex saying something really similar. My ex also broke my heart by saying he didn't love me and the ending brought me back to that point in time in my life. To be honest, I totally cried.
