reviewText: This game really, really isnt for everyone. That being said though, I liked it quite a bit.Its quite short (took me less than an hour to complete) and its inner game gameplay consists of clicking something and waiting.  However, the outside go game gameplay (that sounds weird but stick with me) in exploring Nina's desktop and looking at her life through her own eyes is an incredibly immersive and rewarding experience. Even smaller details, such as hearing the sound of Nina's mouse clicking when you click the mouse immerses you as her. I also have to give major props to Nina for putting her body so out there, as I can imagine the backlash she might receive for it. Another thing i have to commend is the dialogue and general VO. Its not the best or most hollywood-esque sounding lines in a game, far from that in fact. As someone with a long distance girlfriend, it was incredible to see how naturally and closely it resembled my own relationship, at least at the begginnig. It feels like two akward people falling in love while playing a game, as opposed to two actors reading lines. In that sense its more a Silent Hill 2 style of voice acting, minus the creepiness, as opposed to an Until Dawn approach. So I do like this game, but I know fully its not for everyone. If you have the money to spare, then there is an interesting a unique autobiographical game here quite unlike most other things on the market.

reviewText: Having read some blogs on this game I felt I had to give it a try. It's only £5 so not much to lose. Having played it, I don't feel it is worth the price. I want to like it because i've wanted FMV and Choice games to be successful since I played Sewer Shark on the Mega CD! I have played Emily is Away and found that to be excellent, but this is basically just a short film with a very frustrating 'game' played whilst you're talking. I understand the concept is they meet playing games, but why'd it have to be so very annoying? I think people in their teens and early twenties may appreciate the story more. When you turn 30 you forget all the mushy stuff and instead worry about pensions and mortgages. Maybe a version about transfering credit card balances and changing house insurance might be more suited to me.\n\nSo, If you're under 20, smile at kitten videos and don't remember MTV when it used to play Music AND this game drops below the price of a film rental (£2.99) then give it a go. It'll take you little more than an hour to complete and most of that will be spent playing the worst game ever (the game within this game - I cannot describe how awful it is). I find the script corny, but i'm thirty-six and therefore have no idea how the youth of today speak, maybe it's shockingly accurate. I just don't know. Emily is away is cool though. It's similar in a sense and it is free and the point of download. If you like it you can donate. So, yeah, go play Emily is away because its free and better. Play Cibele if you're under 20 - I don't understand the adult rating on this game - spend lots of time on Tumblr and want some video and talking in your game.

reviewText: Despite the clunky mechanics within the point and click MMO within the game, I found myself really immersed in Cibele. It was a nostalgia trip to my own days falling in love with people on the other side of a video game screen. I enjoyed sifting through her desktop to uncover her different thoughts and feelings, her past. Some of the dialogue was a little cringe-inducing, but I feel like my own chats from FFXI days would probably be even more so. It did make a small impact on me, and I won't forget about Cibele anytime soon. That is, until I do. Just like I forget the naive days of playing an MMO in my teens, as I grow older and know much, much better than to fall in love with a stranger.

reviewText: I wasn't sure what to think about Cibele at first glance, but word of mouth from peers had me intrigued to say the least. What I found was an utterly engrossing experience, that took me back to a strange part of my life. I felt slightly ashamed about the world I lived in when I was 19. While I don't regret it, playing Cibele trudged up some thoughts I hadn't dealt with in over a decade. It captivated me, and more importantly made me reflect on my life as a teen entering adulthood and how the internet shaped it.\n\nFor anyone who grew up in AOL chat, or lost in an MMO community, Cibele is a journey well worth experiencing even if it lasts a little over an hour.

reviewText: This one really sucked me in. I found the format very engaging, it was almost like becoming another person for a short while. I suspect repeated playthroughs would be very much the same (you make very few decisions during gameplay) but even so, I enjoyed going along for the ride.

reviewText: A short, yet touching game.  Those late nights chatting, talking, listening, playing, they may not mean anything to a lot of people.  But for those that grew up online, that made virtual, faraway friends, this game reaches into a very deep part of their soul.  This game reminds me of the first time I was challenged by the virtual/reality divide, when I was no longer able to just pretend this person only existed within my computer.  It reminded me of my first love, of late nights and early mornings and long days and long phone calls and heartbreak and sadness and reflection and resolve.  It touched a part deep within my memories that I'd nearly let go.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm at a disadvantage: I don't play online games and I barely used the internet when I was a teenager (few did, it was the early 90s) but Cibele was still compelling to play. I could certainly relate to connecting with an unseen person online, even to the point of developing feelings for that stranger, wondering what might happen if we met in real life. That Cibele can deliver a story like that speaks to the power of interactive fiction. This wouldn't be nearly as engrossing if it was just video; the act of playing the game (by means of playing a game INSIDE the game, very clever) makes you feel in control, even if you cannot control" Nina herself. And even though I had a strong guess as to how the story would play out
date: I was still hooked to see how it happened."

reviewText:
Its tempting to be overly harsh on this game as it fell below my expectations. At the same time that would be unfair given that it was a small budget/indie artsy" game thats probably the first to tell the story and provide the experience of an actual online relationship forming and the awkward transition into reality that may or may not live up to expectations. For anyone that's been through this (I have) it will be a sentimental trip and hopefully not a painful one. The awkwardness of it all had me screaming "oh ffs is just so hard to admit you like each other?" haha

Anyway.. the weakest part of it is the game within a game as other reviews have said. It is still ultimately a "symbolic representation" of MMO grinding and it's helpful to see it as that rather than a represnetation of the game they're actually supposed to be playing that got them so hooked. In that respect it is hard to envision anyone actually wanting to play it much less spend large portions of their life in there.

Anyway
date: yes I recommend the game but more as a slightly more interactive visual novel than usual and overall I'm glad it was made. I got the game as a bundle but wouldn't have regretted spending anything less than $5 on it"

reviewText:
Cibele's strength is how it puts you in the protagonist's shoes through the game's desktop interface and its game within a game aspects. There are a few short FMV cutscenes which set the real world setting and tone (like showing Nina sitting in front of her computer, framing the game around the idea you are playing as the girl playing the game on her computer). For the bulk of the game, you interact with Nina's desktop and play a fictional MMORPG. You can browse old photos of Nina, look at her drawings, and read through her blogs, poems, chatlogs, and emails. In the actual MMORPG, you move an avatar around the screen (you don't actually cast spells or attack; this is done automatically), chat with your online friends, and listen to conversations between Nina and Blake. The core of the story, and the heart of Cibele overall, is the dynamic between Nina and Blake, two awkward people who end up having a relationship through an MMO.

There are some rough spots around the edges, like some of the FMV could have been shot a little better and the game Nina plays could have been more interesting, or at least easier to navigate the avatar around the game world (even though playing the game within the game isn't really the point of Cibele). That said, I really enjoyed the overall experience. Cibele feels like a passion project about a very specific type of experience. It isn't an elaborate or complex game. Instead Cibele is more focused about throwing itself out there. It's about capturing the intimacy of Nina's story.

The framing device, the pieces of information scattered throughout Nina's computer, and the intimate nature of Blake and Nina's conversations come together to tell a unique story that is enhanced by how the game is presented.

reviewText: I really enjoyed how immersive this game was, and I feel like a lot of things that people are most critical of are in fact this games strengths. My own gaming and online experiences are very different from the ones in Cibele, but I think that the abrupt end, the fact that it wasn't completely fleshed out and straightforward, and the discomfort of it mirror what a lot of my own experiences flirting online with friends and trying to navigate someone else's true feelings in a limited amount of time and in constrained environments. I do want more, and that's a good thing. But then, most of my favorite songs are well under two minutes and I adore short stories and films.

reviewText:
First, lets get this out of the way- yes, the game is short. The reviews I read stated around 2 hours of playtime, it was around 90 minutes for me. If that's a deal breaker, read no further.

This is more akin to watching a slice-of-life film than playing a game. There are some diablo-esque combat in it, but it's mostly there to keep your fingers busy while waiting for chat replies. If you were a fan of Gone Home, this will probably appeal to you as well.

The story itself was enjoyable. You get several glimpses into the life of a young female gamer, with all the complexities and layers that entails. This isn't about a plot heavy story, its about story telling for the sake of illumination. We are shown scenes from this girls life, and then, abruptly, it is over. There is a short note at the end, but beyond that the viewer is left to draw their own conclusions.

While I found this highly enjoyable, I definately felt there were several areas that were lacking (warning, possible spoilers ahead). First of all, I felt like not enough time was spent dealing with the character of Blake. Here is a person who is clearly suffering from some deep emotional and psychological issues, yet, it is mostly used to prolong the tension and buildup to the story's romantic plot. There was so much more room to develop this further, to really look into what effect this has had on the young man, and those around him.

Second, I felt like the music was...somehow off. It is overly dark and dramatic, and felt like it would be more at home in a suspensful horror film. I kept waiting for the plot twist to turn out that one of the two characters was a serial killer or something, but when the story ends on a quiet note, it feels very out of place.. It's certainly not a deal breaker, but I feel like the game could have been better served with something more mellow.

reviewText: Cibele is a game I had heard nothing but good things about. VICE, Wired, and a few other blogs I follow had all given it glowing reviews. As a woman who loves video games, I get very excited when I see games written by women, and I gladly shelled out the eight-something dollars for the game. However, after playing it, I was left rather unimpressed. I got through the game in just under an hour, which was disappointing. (Though, perhaps I didn't spend enough time clicking around on Nina's 'desktop.) The premise of the game is interesting. Nina, a college student, falls in love with another player on an MMORPG, named Ichi. The game follows the romance and its eventual demise. I liked this premise, and how she decided to go about presenting it- it reminded me of myself when I was younger, with the selfies, anime wallpaper, and chat logs of my friends. The user can click around Nina's 'desktop', read her emails and look at her pictures- some of which are intimate tokens of affection. This is interesting but there is not enough information to give us backstory on Nina or Ichi, but is a nice touch. The game itself, where Nina + Ichi have their voice chats, is beautiful. The landscapes are lush and the textures are very pleasant. The 'combat' is simple- you just click on a monster to allow Nina's characeter to attack it. While aesthetically it's great, the story just isn't there- which is primiarly while I played it. It was a good, if light, story of first love. The music is beautiful and so is the art. I felt like this was a good attempt at a story game and I do apprecaite it, so if you can buy it I recommend you do. It's entertaining and visually, very nice- but you can skip it.

reviewText: I can't remember any game where I felt I understood the character. Heck, so few games actually have a well-written character. But, it is the only game I've ever played where I felt connected to a character and that is really special.

reviewText:
I got this game in a Humble Bundle so I would say it's worth it if you get it for $1 or $2. It's not a game as much as it is a story, and design really immerses you into the life of this geeky teen girl as she deals with her online crush.

A lot of people might be saying the ending is unsatisfying, which is what I felt initially, but I think that it was pretty true to life. Some people in this world are jerks and you never get an explanation. It's just a crappy thing that happened but oh well, that's life. Try not to so naive next time. In a way I think the game got that message across.

I was actually surprised that I was affected by the ending because I felt the main character, regardless of I judged her decisions. Maybe because I remember being stupid and cringey at that age when it came to guys. I feel this game achieved something no other game has before for me, which was let me slip into someone else's place to effictively. I felt I was seeing things no other person should see, that I was in this situation with Ichi, that I was having my heart messed around with. It was weird, but I'm glad I played it. I really want to see more games exploring something like this because it felt very intimate. I would recommend it if you want to just be part of a story but I wouldn't read to many reviews on it because part of what makes the game good, much like a crush, is not knowing how it will pan out.

PROS:
I enjoyed being able to browse the desktop and read/reply to messages, it was just a fun design and one I really want to see more of this.
Nice addition of real life scenes along with game-play
Just cool idea as a whole

CONS:
Could have expanded on the ending
Hissi level was way to difficult to navigate around and felt badly done

reviewText: I'm not the kind of person that thnks not  agme is a valid critique in general. Some of my favourite games are point and click adventure games, I like the idea of an interactive story with no real choices. I'm also a big fan of short games. I like playing through a game in one sitting, or a few more as well. I like a short well pollished story that I can enjoy once and then move onto the next thing. I don't like wasting my time.\n\nAll that in mind, this game ends way too early, and the gameplay get sin the way on enjoying the story. It woudl be better if there was either much less gameplay, or much better gameplay that din't feel liek a chore you had to get through to get to the next bit of plot. The plot really isn't worth it by the way. I got this in the Humble Narative Bundle, I was excited that it was short and I could just run through it but I think I would have prefered not to have played it. For anyone wondering whetehr there are twists in the story, or if it has a message it doesn't at all. It says based ona true story because this stuff literally happens all the time. The plot can literally be summed up in a couple of lines; a guy and a girl meet on an online game, they start swapping pictures and chatting, he says he doesn't want to date, they meet up and sleep together, he says he doesn't love her . How is that a worthwhile story to tell. If I paid any more than  I did for it I would be upset.

reviewText:
This is the worst game I've ever played since Home Improvement on SNES. This game sounded like a good idea on paper, but in execution, fails miserably. Here is my review for Cibele by Nina Freeman.
Story:
Nina Freeman meets someone named Blake online on an MMO, and over time, the two become closer and closer together, to the point of wanting to meet each other. The story slowly grew on me. I did like the growing attraction between the two.
Graphics:
Terrible. Looks like an early 90's point and click game. I've seen worse graphics, though.
Sounds:
The dialogue might be the best part of this game. It is excellently done and can even provide quite a few laughs. The sound effects sound dated for 2015.
Controls:
The controls are so bad I cannot even describe them. Play the game and see for yourself.
Replay:
No replayability. The whole thing can be completed in less than 45 minutes. The first time I played this game, I beat it in 43 minutes.
Final Verdict:
45 minutes of gameplay for 9 dollars? Are you kidding me? On top of all that, the game gives you a This game never even happened" type of ending. Skip this game. I think I want a personal apology from Nina herself
date: and also a full refund of what I payed for this game. I've been playing video games for over 20 years
recommended: and this is the worst FMV game I have ever played so far."

reviewText:
I really thought I would love Cibele, and even though it's a nice and fairly unique experience I ended up just liking it. The strong points are the thematic choices, the exposed nakedness of this insight into another person's stumbling steps into the world of relationships. However where it mainly falls flat is in it's lack of punchline to both the main story beats and the sub plots. It builds a great atmosphere and insight but then falls flat when it all comes to a rather sudden conclusion.

In the end I'd still recommend this to anyone interested in unique takes on interactive story telling. This might not be the best shining example, but it's well worth the time just to experience and perhaps broaden your perspective on this specific emotional subject.

2/5

reviewText:
I would see this more as an 'interactive novel', rather than a game. It isn't a game, since my actions had no impact. It doesn't take the story into another direction, neither does it impact the ending.

Cleared this within an hour, and the amount of content was kind of disappointing.

There were attempts to make it more like a game, via the 'mini-game' which was supposed to be the mmorpg the protagonist was playing. However, to put it simply, the gameplay was extremely boring and it felt more like a chore I needed to get through to advance the story.

Given the reviews I've read on other sites, I was extremely disappointed by the experience I had in Cibele. The real-life cutscenes are weird, and the voiceover of the two main characters flirting sounded really unnatural. Even though a good story could have salvaged it, I felt that the plot (or what was revealed in Cibele, since it's based on a true story) was poorly developed and it left me thinking that I shouldn't have paid for this game at all.

I would not recommend this to anyone.

reviewText:
Interesting autobiographical vignette into someones life at specific moments in time, filtered through their computer desktop, online game world and avatar.   Cibele invites you to explore the perspective of the naive central protagonist (Nina) and her burgeoning online romance; with all the embarresment, awkwardness and uncertainty you might expect, cocurrent with typical (maybe satirical) MMO grinding.

There is very little player agency given you are emphatically put in someone elses position.  You get to know the proganist by having unfettered access to her computer files including photos, old poems, blog posts and chat posts.  The result is uncomfortably voyueristic, and the effective use of cut-scenes to deliniate between the 'real' and the 'virtual' adds to this.

The relationship between the real and the virtual worlds is a major theme as the 'virtual' is interrogated both as a space that facilitates genuine openness, sharing and connection, but also carefully cultivated representations and fantasy/projection.   The relationship itself and the love interest are open to interpretation from our limited perspective; we can chart how events unfold and transcribe what was said, but never really know their thought processes or intentions.  Just what they choose to show us.

...And isn't that always the way?

reviewText:
I can completely understand why Cibele could grab a player into its narrative. After playing it, I find it weird that I wasn't drawn into it myself. Part of the reason I think it didn't fully connect with me was the game within the game. While listening to the characters voice chat players are tasked with playing a fake MMO. The gameplay in this MMO is terrible.

It's buggy, it's laggy (my machine is more than capable of a lagfree experience so I don't know where that came from), and it's uninspired. One could argue that it isn't too important if the gameplay is solid when the story is so lovingly told. I would argue that means the gameplay has to be even better. Tell me an inovative story (which they did for games), but also give some innovative gameplay.

Simple things like polishing it up, making sure it runs properly would have done enough that I wouldn't be distracted by it (which sadly it took me out of the story). Maybe have Nina's character logout of the game after a fight with Blake? (something like in Depression Quest when agency was purposefully taken away from the player can be pretty impactful) That would require a slight restructuring of the story but still.

Aside from the fake MMO () gameplay it was good. I hope the developers use it as a learning experience and make something where all the aspects are as good as the story.

A few side observations/suggestions:

1. Why does a mouse click sound play at the desktop when my actual mouse makes a sound? Super nitpicky, that one

2. Try to invest in a better camera for any future live action scenes and get a director (rent a camera/get a film student)

3. The bosses in the MMO would often go out of bounds and pathfinding sucked, this made me frusterated which wasn't fun

reviewText: I bought this the day it came out and was pretty much going in blind. I was compelled by the small bit of info I heard about the story direction this game goes. After beating it in about 90 minutes I can say i was mildly satisfied with it overall. Not much here in terms of gameplay, although that's kind of the point. I enjoyed the story a lot early on and I think it did a great job overall conveying what a lot of relationships can be like here in the 21st century. The core gameplay is very basic and just has you pointing and clicking through a ficticious MMO while the two main characters interact over voice chat.  It doesn't sound like much but the dialogue kept me interested enough to want to see what would happen next. The ending wasn't terrific but this was a unique experience that I did enjoy and the main female protaganist (and game designer) deserves a lot of credit for opening herself up the way she did and sharing a very personal journey. Solid overall game    7/10

reviewText: This game is fitting into a genre of really exciting, experimental, and vulnerable kind of interface-driven games, similar to Her Story, which came out earlier this year. It captures a certain kind of relationship, and a certain age, very beautifully, and with a very light touch. It's a relatively quick game to play through, but it has a substantial amount of replay value - you can go back and reexamine the game the same way you might dissect your own old diaries. It's very moving, and a totally unique experience. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
A one hour game about an otakuish girl's first love. Which happens to be an online crush. With a very soft erotic scene with the game's author herself as a bonus.

Pros :

- not too bad looking (the game, not the game's author). :P
- depicts quite well what happens when you get an online crush I guess (I don't know, I'm an alpha male, so I tend not to do that kind of stuff more than 20 minutes per girl). :P
- got to know what happens in the head of an otakuish girl having an online crush.

Cons :

- got to know what happens in the head of an otakuish girl having an online crush : I really cannot care less about something, but maybe it might interest you (never know...).
- gameplay is boring, even for a narrative game
- Feels kind of flat in the end
- an end that comes within one hour, with no rerunability whatsoever.
- 9 euros for this is way, way, way too expensive.

Still I recommend that game to support the devs and give them a chance to produce a proper story, for the experience which was for me a kinda of different, mega cd-girlysh approach to videogaming.

reviewText:
Cibele is, at its heart, an interactive love letter. To first loves, and first losses. To yearning, to heartbreak, and to a young woman's first attempts at learning to love online.

Cibele is set in a world that is familiar to all of us-- a desktop, complete with an anime-esque magical girl background, chatlogs, downloads folders, files filled with old photos, and the glittering crystal icon of the title character's favorite MMO.

Picking through these literal snapshots of autobiography (the game designer herself features in all of them) helps piece together the portrait of a very creative and emotionally vulnerable young woman.

Cibele/Nina, with her tremendous self doubt, is human and heartfelt. Her story is one that is uncomfortably familiar to many of us... Going online in search of the love and human companionship she craves, she grapples with inexperience, insecurity, and trying to love someone who does not want to be loved.

The ending is poignant and painfully real. Not everyone is as perfect as they seem. I love you
date: unfortunately, is no guarantee.\n\nTHE VERDICT: Recommended for those who like a realistic love story, interactive emotional journeys, and lots of delectable Final Fantasy/MMO/Anime/Manga references.

reviewText:
This isn't a game. Lemme get that out there right away. The gameplay is merely a means to hold you up so that the voiceovers can do their work. That said, it simulates mmo grinding extremely well.

This is the short story of one person's experience in an online relationship, molding together themes from both first loves to young loves. It doesn't matter that it happens to take place online; these feelings are generally universal amongst most human beings, perhaps being unknown to the absolute fringe most antisocial.

This work seems specifically to be an interesting act of coping with what was obviously a rough period in her life. Or, as many people have experienced, an amazing period that ended in such a way that it made all that time completely horrible.

Is this specific work relatable to everyone, though? No. Not everyone went through the same internet-specific relationships the author did. Many more have nowadays, and even more will in the near future, but someone looking for a video game won't find such a thing here. Those who did have such a relationship probably heard every line spoken or written in this game in their own life off-script, with just the names changed. Most of these lines are even universal to facetoface relationships.

Poor things: the cinematography is somewhat lackluster. It's not bad for an amateur work, but each scene didn't seem to speak video-wise the same way the emotions were coming out audio-wise. I don't really review movies, though, so I guess I can't give good criticisms here.

Blake's voice actor wasn't nearly as good as Nina's (Nina herself? I didn't check lmao) as delivering awkwardness. His lines felt just a bit forced when he is supposed to be a charismatic guild leader. Personal chats are always different, but the way he is presented and the way he acts seem to not synergize.

And, of course, the gameplay being nonexistent.

Overall, I related to this work, and therefore it was worth playing. Was it worth the gate cost? Probably not, but that doesn't bother me much.

reviewText:
This is such a weird one, but I felt really compelled to write a review and share some thoughts on this.

*Spoilers Ahead!*

Cibele is essentially a story being told with some light gameplay interaction thrown in. I'd hardly even qualify it as a game with the exception of the basic point-n-click gameplay of the online" game you're playing and talking to the other main character in the story with. This game is actually probably my least favorite part of the entire experience - the controls are clunky
date: the pathfinding is awful and there's no strategy to it at all. You're just clicking on an enemy
recommended: watching your characters attack it for a while
hoursPlayed: and then you repeat that about 100 times as the dialogue progresses.\n\nDespite the poor gameplay
voteText: it actually does capture the feeling of completely tuning out on the game you're playing and focusing on who you're talking to while playing. In Cibele you aren't really playing a character and you aren't making any kind of impact on the world
helpfulPercent: you're just watching the story play out and occasionally doing something like reading an email or looking at a photo which will trigger further conversation.\n\nThe pacing is kind of a mess. Each act has a big time-skip in between
votesHelpful: and although you're supposed to assume that the 2 main characters have gotten closer as time has gone on
votesTotal:
the conversation just kind of starts to lull around halfway through and they seem to almost repeat themselves at times.

*Major spoilers ahead*

Although I like the story overall
votesFunny: the time-skip and so much of this story seemingly being left out does not do it any favors. The first two acts seem like a relationship building up
commentsCount: but the 3rd act is odd. It starts off with a lot of very similar dialogue to the previous act
column16: then suddenly things start to escalate
column17: and then suddenly things don't work out and it's over. This game doesn't give you any time to process what you're learning about the characters
column18: or to really even grow attached to any of them.\n\nI know I sound really critical about this game but there are some things I really liked. Browsing Nina's computer is surprisingly compelling and there's a lot of attention to detail about what you'll find on there - things are labelled by date and you can go look at her old blogs and website pages from when she was young
column19: and as the story moves on you can learn about her by looking through her computer.\n\nThe dialogue between the two characters
column20: particularly in the early parts of the game
column21: is well-acted and sounds really natural for the most part. At times when I was spacing out in the boring gameplay sections listening to them talk
column22: I felt like I was actually in a skype call with two people just listening to them talk. Even though some have criticized the dialogue for being strange and even creepy
column23: I think for the most part
column25: it seems about right for two people falling for each other online. At least from my own experience (more on that in a bit.)\n\nLastly
column27: if not surreal touch. It almost makes me feel like I'm playing one of those old Sega CD games or something
column28: where it's trying to be like an interactive movie or something.\n\nThis game did strike a bit of a personal chord with me
column29: and maybe that's what made me want to keep playing it until the end (not that that takes very long anyway.) My first (and to date
column30: only) relationship was one that started
column32: and ended online. We met through World of Warcraft and ended up being together for just a bit over 2 years before we drifted apart. A lot of the dialogue in the early parts of the game really reminded me of getting to know that girl as we mindlessly grinded away on the game together
column33: and it became the background of what we were really focusing on together - getting to know each other
column34:
and seeing our feelings grow stronger over time.

*Last spoilers ahead*

The ending is really a shame. Not because the relationship didn't work out - that stuff happens obviously. But it's just so.. abrupt. I sat there staring at the credits for a few seconds in disbelief. I couldn't believe it. The game really should have had at least one or two more acts to really tell the story
column35:
and it shouldn't have ended the way it did.


I really had to think of if I wanted to recommend this game to others or not
column36: but I think at the end of the day it does something unique and there is a lot of charm to it. If you've been in an online-only relationship
column38: you might find this game interesting."

reviewText: TL;DR -- If you've been in a relationship with someone you met in a video game, Cibele will take you on a feels trip down memory lane.  If not, you will probably not find it as enjoyable.\n\nLet's get the obvious out of the way first: this isn't a game.  The gameplay" of the MMO portion is terrible and token
date: and I believe it's designed that way -- the point is to zone out the actual game and focus on the various characters interacting with each other.  Any veteran MMO player can understand that feeling well.\n\nI've been in various online relationships before
recommended: and each act of this game reminded me a little of a different element of each of them.   I wish the game was longer -- it could use another act between the first and second to build up some tension

reviewText:
Cibele is a short affair that has you browsing Nina's desktop over the course of several months. You can read emails, view archived posts from her blog, and look at pictures. This all helps give a sense of the kind of person you're playing as, and I highly recommend exploring the desktop before launching the MMO every time you can. It helps give a sense of what's going on outside of Nina's conversations with her internet boyfriend. Some of it is cute, some of it is a bit sad.

In the MMO, you mostly talk to Ichi while mindlessly clicking away at enemies. The conversations are not terribly romantic considering the subject matter, but the awkward exchanges really ring true to me as someone who is also very introverted and has had an online relationship. There's also other players who will try to chat with you while you talk to Ichi, and you're free to engage or ignore them as you please.

I hesitate to say much more for fear of spoilers. The things you've heard about how this game explores relationships in the digital age, that's all there. There's also a lot of almost cringe-inducingly nostalgic details sprinkled throughout that feel very true to life. I felt feelings with this game.

reviewText: Cibele is an intensely emotional and personal experience. Nina Freeman invites us to remember what it's like to forge relationships online and in-person, experience love and heartbreak, and deal with the awkwardness of intertwining a real-world life and a virtual one. If you've been through a difficult and complex relationship of any kind, the game will strike a meaningful chord with you. It doesn't try to sugar-coat or even provide hope for the often harsh realities of relationships, while also not being so bleak so as to push you to not want relationships at all. It encourages you to go out and experience all the positive and negative emotions the world has to offer, and legitimizes that experiencing it through an online game is no less valid than experiencing it in person. This valuable experience is wrapped up in some wonderful art and music, and a clever and well-thought out interface. If you grew up on the internet in the early 2000's, you will find yourself in Cibele.

reviewText: A strong and disturbing game, and a very smart case of form and content matching.\nIf you are looking for good gameplay or efficient time/$ ratio, you will probably be disappointed. But if you are interested in seeing this medium used to make us feel things and experience stories in a way that no other medium could, Cibele is definitely worth playing.

reviewText: I think, perhaps, the beauty of this game comes mostly in its vulnerability. If one didn't have a formative experience similar to that of the kind depicted in this game, it very well might leave the player feeling bored, annoyed, or even confused. If, like me, you spent a lot of your youth playing online games, making distant friends, and perhaps even awkwardly exploring your sexuality in the age of the internet, this game is almost sure to resonate with you on some level.\n\nMany of the reviews here seem to critique the game on the awkward, at times cringe-inducing dialogue, as well as the repetitive mindless clickfest. I think they miss that both of these are completely intentional and very, very realistic. This is not an experience meant to be a fun, engaging game. It is meant to evoke feelings of youthful uncertainty, of unspoken longing for connection and love, for self-acceptance in a world where you can hide behind a screen. It is a digital snapshot of growing up. If that sounds boring to you, I highly encourage you to pass over this game. If that sounds like someone you used to know (i.e. your younger self), something tells me you'll be thinking about this game for days to come.

reviewText: Cibele is a short game that tells the story of two people bonding over an online video game. Eventually, this bond turns into more than just friendship which you can tell by the way the two talk to one another and by going through Nina's personal effects on her computer. The entire story is seen and told through private documents and conversations, you feel as if you do not belong (which can be somewhat uncomfortable) but, it makes the game more intimate on a more personal level. Overall, the game is beautifully crafted and the story is a meaningful one, one that hits way too close to home for some. Thank you for all your hardwork on this game, Devs, I have been waiting for this game and it did not dissapoint.

reviewText:
Cibele is a narrative experience about the story of Nina and Blake, two people that met and iniated a relationship through a MMO.

The story is presented from Nina's point of view. You will interact with her computer desktop where you will find many photos, exchanged emails and texts, chat logs and so on. It feels eerily personal and voyeuristic, like you are really looking through another person's life and personal thoughts and situations.

You progress through the story by playing through a ♥♥♥♥♥♥me. There isn't much to that game itself, just clicking mobs  and bosses until they die( aahahah, to be fair that does capture what you end up doing in many many mmos).  Nina goes on raids with Blake, while talking to him through voice chat , and that's where their relationship grows. You also can text with some of Nina's friends as well.

As you go on, the desktop will change and will have new texts, new photos , etc, that will reflect Nina's state of mind and relationships. You can see how her herself changes throughout, as well as her friends. The relation ship of Nina and Blake  also develops at a steady pace, starting from some slight flirts to more deep conversations and then even talks of a deeper relationship. The dialog feels quite realistic and natural (well, it ressonated with my awkward teenager years at least) The very personal point of views keeps the plot quite engaging, it really feels like looking into someone else's life, personality and fears.

For people who like narrative experiences like The Begginer's Guide, I definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
This review is in video form here.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ah9SUjA5tfE&feature=youtu.be

When video games try to forcefully be artistic, it can feel abrasive.  But when a video game is used as an expression of the creator, it becomes an artistic experience.

Cibele is one of those experiences.  An autobiographical shortfilm/and mmo simulator, Cibele tells the emotional and intimate story of a college girl, named Nina, falling in love with a man she meets in an MMO.

When starting the game up and perusing through personal files I felt voyeuristic and uncomfortable.  But, the narrative handed to me was eventually immersive, anxious to see what next development was unfolded became increasingly motivating, and I felt as if I was the girl herself.

The gameplay is boiled down to a computer simulator.  I looked at emails, went on websites and viewed personal photos.  Another icon, that looks similar to a Final Fantasy crystal is present. Clicking this icon throws you into a virtual MMO.  Inside the mmo you can respond to messages in a similar way you respond to text messages in the game Catherine, fight monsters and bosses (it felt like busywork by the first ten minutes I did it).  You have a voice chat fully voice acted by the young woman and the boy who she is playing the game with.  It’s very well done, and the art has a very colorful pastel look to it, even if the animations can seem a little sloppy.

The writing is realistic, but also poetic.  Nina Freeman’s English Literature degree really shines in this area.  While the voice acting may be hard to get used to at first, your suspension of immersion should be set into the characters footsteps in order to fully enjoy the story.

With an ending that’s very poignant, sad, and powerful.  Cibele is an enjoyable solid experience that will keep your attention for the meager hour it asks of your time.  Tiny details, like the whirring of the computer in the background just add to the overall enjoyment.  I felt frustrated with Cibeles story and gameplay, but I also felt rewarded for the moral I retained.

Years from now the gaming medium may talk about Cibele and it’s uniqueness with how it presented storytelling, or it may not.  With either outcome, Nina has produced her passion, and she should be commended and congratulated for that.  With that conclusion, I recommend Cibele for people who are fascinated by relationships on the internet, or individuals who enjoy artistic interactive experiences.

reviewText:
Cibele is a short, interesting, and deeply personal game. It's a semi-autobiographical (and semi-voyeuristic) look into a geeky college-aged girl's experience with love and sex,

The gameplay is split into two parts: looking at pictures and documents concerning your past and present life, and playing Valtameri, a fictional MMO with a really pleasant art style. Combat in the MMO world is simpily just clicking on something and watching a meter go down, but you're also juggling reading emails, replying to chat messages, and listening to the two main characters talk, so it's not a big deal considering how the game is structured. It would have been nice to have a cooldown or two, though. The game had framerate drops in the last area, but again, not a big deal with the type of gameplay it has.

The price is kind of steep, but you should be satisfied if you know what you're getting into. It's a nice game that reminds us of how dorky we used to be when we were younger.

reviewText:
Overall, a fairly enjoyable game. The story was good, and I felt compelled to keep reading and chatting throughout.

The actual gameplay parts (inside the game within a game) were pretty difficult to navigate. It could've had some better pathing, or at least a more open map so you don't get stuck on corners every other step. A few of the chat logs were broken (unreadable), but they were few and far between. Still, I feel like I missed parts of the story that I would have enjoyed.

I'd say play/buy it but with the caveat that you know what you're buying:
-It says 90-120 minutes, but I played really slowly and read everything and was finished in about an hour.
-No actual nudity (sorry bros).
-No real gameplay mechanics, almost entirely reading.

If this is what you're looking for absolutely give it a shot.

reviewText:
That was interesting. This is a game where you experience the online life of a nerdy 19 year-old girl, discovering romance, love, and sex. In the game, you can look through photos and text files on her desktop and you'll play her favorite MMO and listen to conversations between her and her crush. It's also quite short.

If that sounds interesting to you, you should probably just play it right now. As for my take...

The game was surprisingly jarring, though I don't mean that in a necessarily bad way. You really do feel like you're looking into the personal life of a teenage\young adult girl. I never lived that life, but I think I've come away with a better understanding of what life was like for someone like Nina. The game is separated into acts. The first part of each is browsing files on Nina's desktop. This did feel kind of voyeuristic, especially looking at the kinds of pictures that she'd taken of herself, though other files like poems and blog posts were generally more comfortable to read. There's a lot of text to take in at once. As one who's never been good at following TV and movies, this was a bit difficult, but ultimately rewarding. The real meat of the game is experienced in the sequences taking place within the world of the fictional MMO Valtameri, where you play as Nina's character, Cibele. There isn't a lot to the gameplay and it's thankfully never difficult or confusing, but it really just serves as a backdrop for the in-game voice chat between Nina and her crush, known as ichi"

reviewText: Cibele is everything I want from the interactive media today. It's what I think it needs to advance and validate itself as a democratic, accessible and non-elitist artistic medium (even if this particular case tells a story around videogame culture, that could be better enjoyed if you are into it).\n\nCibele is one of the most interesting things from this year. If you are into unusual narrative techniques, internet and videogame culture, the adult treatment of teen and sexuality themes, and real-life personal stories, you'll probably get something cool from this.

reviewText:
This is a short game that benefits from being played in one sitting.  It's lazer focused on the experience of teenage love through playing an MMO.  It's perhaps the least idealistic romance story I've ever seen.  All the characters are flawed and authentic.  Nina, the protagonist, is self-conscious and unsure.  She craves affirmation from Blake, her MMO boyfriend, but doesn't know how to handle it.  Blake shares these same insecurities.  He is a teenager afterall.  His compliments seem subtly sexist to (e.g. you're good for a girl) and he seems to have trouble valuing people (including himself) for their internal characteristics.

<SPOILERS TO FOLLOW> When the characters do get together it hardly feels like a triumph.  As the game, and their relationship ends, it doesn't feel tragic.  You get released from an (at times) uncomfortably personal look at two young people's lives.  The characters themselves get released from a relationship that probably needed to end for their own growth.  <END SPOILERS>

I can strongly recommend this game because of how honest it feels.  It's uncomfortable to play (for me at least).  The mid-western sensibilities I was raised with make me feel uncomfortable with such an intimate look into a stranger's personal life.  For me, playing through someone else's life like this was more trangressive than any gaming murder spree I've been a part of.

I should mention I encountered a few minor bugs.  A couple chat logs wouldn't open for me and an MMO boss just disappeared for a couple minutes when I was supposed to be hitting it.  Don't let those stop you from playing this though.  The teenage awkwardness of this game gave me the most visceral sympathetic embarrassment I've experienced in a long time and I love the game for that.

I give this game a 10/Teens.

reviewText:
A game that will get you thinking about any of the relationships, friendship or romantic or enemy,you had while playing MMORPGs, it will get you thinking about the ways we represent ourselves in these online spaces, via telling a story about two vulnerable and young players.

For those players who have grown out of playing and living in MMORPG spaces, it's a chance to revisit those thoughts and experiences from back then.

Good voice acting and good characterization. The process of development is commendable, too, as the developer used actual chat logs and pictures and diaries from her past life in creating the story - as is mentioned, it's all based on a true story.

Also if you're here to blindly downvote, maybe this is the sort of game you need to play~

reviewText:
We can't recall ever playing a game quite like Cibele. It is a very thought provoking title, and shows the courage that Nina Freeman had, to put so much of herself out there for us all to see. You can comb through her private pictures, chat logs, live journal blog posts, emails, and more.

So many people out there can relate to the story that this game contains, and all of the awkward friendships, and loves we may have gotten into/or out of.

For the price, the experience, and the story, Cibele is a game that you must try. One of our favorites of 2015. Just be sure to play with headphones, and enjoy the ride.

reviewText: I recommend this game to anyone with an open mind and an interest in alternative games that challenge the very basis of video game culture. I do not think I will ever forget my time playing it. It is remarkably short, which is a very brave thing to do in world where we want our games replayable"... If only more games would accept that sometimes 90 minutes is enough. A lot of this game remainds me of Sherry Turkle's writing on internet culture

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone, but it certainly was an experience that spoke to me.

If you've ever fallen in love over the internet, you will certainly have a deep connection to this game. The way you can go through Nina's computer and read her blog posts, look at her private pictures, and conversations with others seems so invasive. But also tells you who she is without the narrative just telling you. You can really understand her character, and what her insecurities and interests are.

The voice acting was awkward in the most genuine way possible. I liked it a lot. And the cutscenes" of live action segments were very well done and intimate.

I very much reccomend this game to anyone looking for a love story about MMOs and the internet.

https://youtu.be/KkZt2rSKWPs

Edit: oops linked wrong video. sorry about that."

10/10 for story and originality. (The online game she's playing, and you therefore have to play is a bit boring and laggy, but this isn't much of a problem. Besides you really only play it while waiting for chat replies to popup.)

As far as I can tell this is autobiographic. The girl that lived and wrote the story design is also the girl who did the voice and video acting.

She's cute I think I've fallen slightly in love with her. Both for her peronality and looks. :)

reviewText: I strongly recommend getting this game. The use of 'found' objects to tell the story is fresh and provides a very personal-feeling insight into the semi-autobiographical story. Some review unfairly criticize the online game portion as too simplistic. That is a deliberate design choice and allows the player to be able to appreciate the messaging, media, and dialogue that occur while playing. The more complex the online game was, the less players would be able to pay attention to the story being told. There a few times that the dialogue seems a bit too earnest and honest, but that is partially my older perspective looking at younger emotions. It also seems to be a necessary device to keep the plot on track with the length of the game.\n\nTLDR: At $9 the game takes you on an emotional 1.5 hour ride.

reviewText: A game that finds the art and beauty in being a teen who likes anime and hates yourself.  It speaks to me, I found myself relating to the characters and sometimes realized I had said the same things growing up.  It's a love story that's more about not knowing if you're in love than an actual romance, maybe I'm just projecting too much though.  It had some preformance issues, both in acting and sometimes the gameplay got really choppy.  Honestly this has been one of my favorite games this year just because it lets me know that I wasn't the only one like this.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Cibele captures genuinely and perfectly a brief window in a period of online gaming history that resonated powerfully in me. So much of this short experience felt like exactly my own.  So much more was from a perspective I hadn't seen before, either.

Cibele is about budding romance within an MMORPG. But surrounding the story are authentic markers of the time: failed blogs, anime fandom, forums, and the intimacy of sharing photos with friends you'd never met.

My game was RuneScape, or Team Fortress 2. My homes were RuneScape Community and Couch Athletics. I had these conversations. I had those chats. Some of those online friends I met and still know today.

I'm very glad this game exists.

reviewText: Super personal story about falling love with someone on the internet. Who hasn't been there. The game's story is told through dialog, email snippets, and instant messages. It can have a bit of a voyeuristic feel with some of the selfies, but respect to Nina Freeman for really putting herself out there in a mega honest way and retelling a story about bein a silly 19 year old.\n\nI can only assume it appropriately captures the annoyance of dudes hitting on you when you're just wanting to play a game.

reviewText:
David Cage would be proud.

A game about relationships so devoid of any believable human emotions or interactions, you'll make a ten times more emotional experience when asking a stranger where to find the next fastfoodchain.

A more superficial look at relationships is virtually impossible. You don't get to know the characters in any way outside of clicking on random .txt files on a fakedesktop telling you oh, this character likes Anime, FFX and the Matrix movies.

The dialogue consists to 50% only of You're so cute"

reviewText:
This game, for a good majority for it, was extremely relatable for me. And it was, to a degree, uncomfortable to watch the intimacy between the 2 main characters you're introduced to, Nina and Ichi.

But at the same time, this uncomfortable insight to this relationship was quite a emotional. It's not meant to take your fancy. It's meant to show you that actual reality and fickle that is love. And not even that, just the odd social interactions that occur online nowadays.

It's a good game, not because it's tickling a fancy, but it's transferring a message along with a taste of the emotions, in 1 to 2 hours. It's horrifyingly efficient. I think it's a good game. I need to take a breather.

reviewText:
This game is definitely not for everyone. It’s made for a subset of the gamer population. Just by looking at the game, you should be able to tell if this applies to you or not. In short, if you ever experienced some sort of online romance (especially in MMOs), this game was made for you.

That being said, it’s not much of a game. Most of the game is browsing her desktop, or playing the MMO. Perhaps “playing” is too strong a word. You just click on mobs a single time until they die from auto-attacks, then find another and rinse and repeat. The monotony isn’t overly bad as you have multiple in game conversations via text with your other in-game friends at the same time, all the while talking verbally to your love interest. The game is over before any of this should grate on your nerves.

Throw in a few short live-action cut scenes, and that’s all there is to it. It took me just over 90 minutes to do everything this game has, including reading every word and browsing every file. To be fair, this is all advertised on the store page more or less, so the game is upfront in what it is and what it offers. I won’t fault it for that.

What I will fault it for is some of the voice acting. It just didn’t have me convinced at all. Hearing her say “I love you” didn’t have me convinced at all. Wasn’t the best, but it could have been worse.

Again, this was made for certain people in mind. I know I can personally relate to it, and for that reason alone, I appreciate and like it. There was some self-reflection involved, since a few of the actions mirrored my own. So I can’t help but feel for her and relate more than I’d care to admit. Especially knowing it’s a true story.

If any of this is sounds interesting, I’d give it a try… but only when it’s on sale as it’s hard to justify that price point for such a short experience. Otherwise, this probably isn’t for you, and I’d give it a pass.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I have a very difficult time thumbs upping this game, I wish I could be neutral. This game was very personal for me, as I have experienced what she has (at a younger age). I got to re-live the touching and confusing moments that is online (gaming) dating. However, as awesome and awkward as the beginning was, the ending fell very flat. They could have taken it further, but (spoiler alert, but not really) the relationship ends just like that. No build up or anything. I suppose its best that way, it would be even more painful to relive the hard times, but that would be good for me, and others, in a way. Maybe I don't like it as much because it mirrored my feelings so perfectly, then changed and we had nothing in common anymore. I dunno.\n\nOverall, it was an interesting game/interactive story that I applaud Nina for being brave enough to create. Online dating is much more a common thing now.

There are no choices, or really much to do at all, you simply watch the story unfold as you follow the chat and play as 'Cibele'. If for nothing else, it's worth playing for that much.

reviewText:
I didnt expect forums and response to this game to be quite so venemous and aggressive.

I bought this during winter sale for 5$

- The game aspects of it are light. You are either clicking through files and objects on the main characters computer in a voyeuristic fashion or playing a simple MMO-esque game.
- The drive of the game is a combination of FMV clips, emails, photos and Audio conversations between the main character and a man she becomes emotionally involved with in the MMO they play together.
- The story is not partiuclarly unique and brings nothing entirely new to the surface (young people like each other, and they are young so their emotions are unrealiable at best)
- I am 29 years old. I was the main characters age when i was a Freshmen in college. Exchanging messages with girls on facebook and inevitably getting emotionally destroyed were part of my 18-20 year old experience.
- A lightly interactive story about young love, relationship and sex that will resonate with most people of the 21st century.


Conclusion:

- Definetely enjoyed my time with
- It made me feel a viceral emotion, so I believe it succeeded in its goal. Any good story experience, should make me feel something and this did.
- I would recommend it to others
- Its not as revelatory an experience as something like gone home or her story, but for a young developer (i believe there are two of them - Nina and the male actor... i think is also a developer - fact check me) i think this is a fantastic addition to the video game industry

Side Note
- Anyone mentioning gamergate, anita sarkisian or SJWs is a ****ing ♥♥♥♥♥. This game stands on its own. No forced agenda. Just a story. If you can't accept new things into the pantheon of video games then your a ****lord.

reviewText: First off, I agree with other reviews that Cibele is not a game, but more of a story with some interactive elements. However, it is the kind of story that centers around a game, so presenting it in this format makes a lot of sense. IT's also the kind of story that will resonate well with people who were gaming or at the very least active on the Internet during the time frame when this takes place--I saw a lot of myself in Nina, and saw echoes of other past online friendships throughout this story. For that reason, I recomend it, but for those who expect deeper interactivity or more choice within the narrative will not find it here.

reviewText: Short, sweet, and not really all that complicated mechanically. Click around, read notes, and look at pictures. The combat doesn't require you to click thousands of times, just click once on the monster you want to attack, and you will fight it til it dies.\n\nThe story hits close to my own history, as well as the history of a few friends. I'd say it is worth a playthrough.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I absolutely understand why this game has some mixed reviews. The level of interaction is absolutely minimal, the story is linear, and the dialogue can trigger some uncomfortable emotions, especially for anyone familiar (and I'm sure so many of us are) with online romanticsm.

But it is so, so brilliant. This game brings an unexpected level of polish to a very personal story. The linearity of the gameplay culminates in a succint, focused experience.

Even as one of the more slickly produced games at this price point, it's not without its more janky moments. The animation and navigation during the 'in game' moments can lock up at various points and the fake UI can feel difficult to navigate as well.

However, if you can overlook minimal interactivity and clunky UI for atmospheric and emotional storytelling, and you have the right set of expectations going in, I think this is an experience you will enjoy.

reviewText:
Cibele captures genuinely and perfectly a brief window in a period of online gaming history that resonated powerfully in me. So much of this short experience felt like exactly my own.  So much more was from a perspective I hadn't seen before, either.

Cibele is about budding romance within an MMORPG. But surrounding the story are authentic markers of the time: failed blogs, anime fandom, forums, and the intimacy of sharing photos with friends you'd never met.

My game was RuneScape, or Team Fortress 2. My homes were RuneScape Community and Couch Athletics. I had these conversations. I had those chats. Some of those online friends I met and still know today.

I'm very glad this game exists.

reviewText:
David Cage would be proud.

A game about relationships so devoid of any believable human emotions or interactions, you'll make a ten times more emotional experience when asking a stranger where to find the next fastfoodchain.

A more superficial look at relationships is virtually impossible. You don't get to know the characters in any way outside of clicking on random .txt files on a fakedesktop telling you oh, this character likes Anime, FFX and the Matrix movies.

The dialogue consists to 50% only of You're so cute"
recommended: i'm nat! [giggle]"  and the story plays out in such a predictable and boring way

as the game depicts this as an absolute non-issue.

"I want to see you"
"but we live so far apart"
"I'll just tell my mom i wanna visit my cousins and she'll buy me some flight tickets."

And that is literally it.

But the worst thing is the pseudo-MMORPG gameplay.

reviewText:
Most of the problems people mention with this game seem to me to be intentional.

- The dialogue is very awkward.  The characters don't sound like they're out of a Hollywood movie or a blockbuster game.  They aren't supposed to.  Instead, it sounds a lot like an actual voice chat; movie or game dialogue usually is very succinct and to-the-point, while Cibele's meanders much like real conversations.  Overall, the dialogue sounds pretty much like the awkward conversations I had when I was 19.
- Likewise, the characters are not 100% likeable, but they aren't supposed to be.  I did kind of want to reach into the computer and slap some sense into Nina sometimes, but that's easy for me to say now; when I was 19, I was every bit as insecure and self-deprecating in real life as Nina and Blake are in Cibele.
- And, yes, the story is pretty predictable.  If you read the description of the game, you'll probably think, Oh
date: I know how that story ends
recommended:
and you'll probably be right.  That said, I got a lot out of it seeing it from a third-party point of view.  It's one thing to know what'll probably happen; it's another to actually watch it happen without being one of the people involved.
- Cibele is more of a visual novel than a game.  There is a gameplay element to it, and you can poke around a bit on Nina's computer to get glimpses into other parts of her life, but you should approach this more as a movie that you have to interact with rather than as a game where you make your own choices.
- The pseudo-MMO is very simple and repetitive.  However, I think this is essential to the storytelling.  You don't want a complex game here, because that would distract from the story.  Also, when you play an MMO for a while, you get to the point where even a very involved game starts to feel a little repetitive and you can sort of do it on autopilot; the game-within-a-game captures that, where it feels a little grindy and you don't bat an eyelash at checking email and carrying on a conversation with the game being just sort of something you're doing in the background.  (That said, the pathfinding really does suck; it's the top thing I'd change about this game.)
- The ending is a little abrupt.  I think it's supposed to be, though: You feel dumped at the end, a lot like Nina.  It isn't clear if Blake ever talks to Nina again, or if Nina stops playing Valtameri entirely afterward, and I don't think it matters; Cibele is a story about a relationship, and Cibele ends when the relationship ends.  Do I wish I had more insight into Nina's life after the end of the story?  Of course.  That's because I like the character, though, and would like to know more about her; not because I think knowing is essential to the story.

There is one significant negative about the game: the price.  It's a really short game for the money.  On the other hand, I think it's more fair to compare the price to that of a movie or a play rather than a computer game; when viewed in that light, it's a little more reasonable.  That said, the comparatively high cost is why I don't go to many movies or plays--I'd rather spend the money on a computer game that I can play a lot more of.  If you feel the same way, Cibele will be too expensive for you.

Overall, I really enjoyed Cibele.  However, your expectations for this game will dramatically affect your perception of it.  Cibele asks you to have empathy for a character in a way that most games do not, and it requires you to infer a lot about the characters.  If you like indie art films, and you have had a long-distance it's complicated" kind of relationship
hoursPlayed: you'll probably like Cibele.  Otherwise

reviewText:
I beat it in an hour and it's... OK? I guess? It's not really a game so much as a movie with some still shots and text you take in. The bulk of the game, when you're not looking at the pictures and such, is this in-game MMO where you play while this dude hits on you. However, there's no HP or levelling up or anything, so it's basically just a cookie clicker game with some occasionally very cringy dialogue.

I don't want to say too much as the game's so plot-driven, but the guy the main character falls for is so unlikable, she has this pointless relationship and then the game just suddenly ends. So the girl wastes a lot of her time on some jerk, gets used and then there's absolutely no closure. Maybe that's the point? The girl is definitely cute in a nerdy way, which might seem like a pointless or shallow thing to bring up but really, a lot of this game is looking at selfies she took so if for some reason you really don't like how she looks, you've been warned.

I dunno, there's a certain interesting element of voyeurism to the early half of the game (the first 15 minutes!) where you're poking through her things, getting to know who she is and was, and how she got to this point in her life. But a lot of this game is playing the MMO and listening to the whiny dude and neither of them are interesting or likable. If you got it in a bundle or as a gift, I'd say sure, play it, it's too short to really be a big regret. But I wouldn't spend $10 on it, so that's why I gotta give this the thumbs down.

reviewText:
Cibele is a short game about falling in love in an online game.

Viewed as a traditional game, it doesn't really do a lot: the game within the game you play mostly plays itself and there is practically no real player agency. But it is enough to lend some emotional reality to the feeling of getting to know someone online while also giving the player enough opportunity to see what Nina's life is like through her pictures and messages.

It's short (about an hour long) but sweet and feels very personal and emotionally honest. I'd highly recommend this to anyone interested in games experimenting with what the medium can do.

reviewText:
I don't know for sure if the game was entirely based on the creator's personal life, but the story felt a little jarring and abrupt. I feel the writing in general was really dissapointing. There are good elements to this game, it tries to explore complex issues about body image and teenage sexuality. But it stumbles largely because of the characters. I don't want to judge some one's personal life (i.e. if the entire narrative is real life) but Blake just comes across as unlikeable and Nina comes across as a little too naive for her age.

The game inside the game is a real chore. I like walking simulators and other games that have no fail states (like Journey) so that is not my problem, but the amount of interactivity on offer is miniscule and it is only there to push the poorly written dialogues forward. And the visuals are kind of meh..

I honestly hope the creator gives this another go. She seems to have good ideas for a narrative based game that I would really love to play but unfortunately Cibele is not that game.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of flaws which the negative reviews do a good job warning you about. This review is positive because the best part about this game isn;t discussed in those reviews.

The narrative is simple, short, and the writing varies in its quality. All that said, this game manages to create a real sense of intimacy with the protagonist. It's difficult to tell a story that gives the viewer the feeling of being a fly on the wall watching a believable sequence of events play out. It's even harder to tell such a story in way that gives the viewer a reason to be invested in the events.

This game manages both, and is well worth buying (though I would wait for a sale).

reviewText:
Most of the problems people mention with this game seem to me to be intentional.

- The dialogue is very awkward.  The characters don't sound like they're out of a Hollywood movie or a blockbuster game.  They aren't supposed to.  Instead, it sounds a lot like an actual voice chat; movie or game dialogue usually is very succinct and to-the-point, while Cibele's meanders much like real conversations.  Overall, the dialogue sounds pretty much like the awkward conversations I had when I was 19.
- Likewise, the characters are not 100% likeable, but they aren't supposed to be.  I did kind of want to reach into the computer and slap some sense into Nina sometimes, but that's easy for me to say now; when I was 19, I was every bit as insecure and self-deprecating in real life as Nina and Blake are in Cibele.
- And, yes, the story is pretty predictable.  If you read the description of the game, you'll probably think, Oh
date: I know how that story ends
recommended:
and you'll probably be right.  That said, I got a lot out of it seeing it from a third-party point of view.  It's one thing to know what'll probably happen; it's another to actually watch it happen without being one of the people involved.
- Cibele is more of a visual novel than a game.  There is a gameplay element to it, and you can poke around a bit on Nina's computer to get glimpses into other parts of her life, but you should approach this more as a movie that you have to interact with rather than as a game where you make your own choices.
- The pseudo-MMO is very simple and repetitive.  However, I think this is essential to the storytelling.  You don't want a complex game here, because that would distract from the story.  Also, when you play an MMO for a while, you get to the point where even a very involved game starts to feel a little repetitive and you can sort of do it on autopilot; the game-within-a-game captures that, where it feels a little grindy and you don't bat an eyelash at checking email and carrying on a conversation with the game being just sort of something you're doing in the background.  (That said, the pathfinding really does suck; it's the top thing I'd change about this game.)
- The ending is a little abrupt.  I think it's supposed to be, though: You feel dumped at the end, a lot like Nina.  It isn't clear if Blake ever talks to Nina again, or if Nina stops playing Valtameri entirely afterward, and I don't think it matters; Cibele is a story about a relationship, and Cibele ends when the relationship ends.  Do I wish I had more insight into Nina's life after the end of the story?  Of course.  That's because I like the character, though, and would like to know more about her; not because I think knowing is essential to the story.

There is one significant negative about the game: the price.  It's a really short game for the money.  On the other hand, I think it's more fair to compare the price to that of a movie or a play rather than a computer game; when viewed in that light, it's a little more reasonable.  That said, the comparatively high cost is why I don't go to many movies or plays--I'd rather spend the money on a computer game that I can play a lot more of.  If you feel the same way, Cibele will be too expensive for you.

Overall, I really enjoyed Cibele.  However, your expectations for this game will dramatically affect your perception of it.  Cibele asks you to have empathy for a character in a way that most games do not, and it requires you to infer a lot about the characters.  If you like indie art films, and you have had a long-distance it's complicated" kind of relationship
hoursPlayed: you'll probably like Cibele.  Otherwise
voteText: you probably won't."

reviewText:
I beat it in an hour and it's... OK? I guess? It's not really a game so much as a movie with some still shots and text you take in. The bulk of the game, when you're not looking at the pictures and such, is this in-game MMO where you play while this dude hits on you. However, there's no HP or levelling up or anything, so it's basically just a cookie clicker game with some occasionally very cringy dialogue.

I don't want to say too much as the game's so plot-driven, but the guy the main character falls for is so unlikable, she has this pointless relationship and then the game just suddenly ends. So the girl wastes a lot of her time on some jerk, gets used and then there's absolutely no closure. Maybe that's the point? The girl is definitely cute in a nerdy way, which might seem like a pointless or shallow thing to bring up but really, a lot of this game is looking at selfies she took so if for some reason you really don't like how she looks, you've been warned.

I dunno, there's a certain interesting element of voyeurism to the early half of the game (the first 15 minutes!) where you're poking through her things, getting to know who she is and was, and how she got to this point in her life. But a lot of this game is playing the MMO and listening to the whiny dude and neither of them are interesting or likable. If you got it in a bundle or as a gift, I'd say sure, play it, it's too short to really be a big regret. But I wouldn't spend $10 on it, so that's why I gotta give this the thumbs down.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I got this game because on the outside it appeared to be a game similar to 'Emily Is Away', which I thoroughly enjoyed. However, it seems that adding a boring, repetitive, 'click to kill the enemy' game within the game, in addition to voice acting, often creepy dialogue, and short live-action cutscenes, has made this game a whole lot worse. Both protagonists are ultimately unlikeable and I found myself cringing at the amount of 'flirting' goes on between them. This feels like a gullible child's first internet 'love' (which is what it is based on), yet I'm powerless to do anything about it; I can't stop Nina despite already knowing exactly how this is going to play out. I noticed that IGN is quoted to have said 'The most authentic, romantic game I've ever played' which is just laughable; there is no romance, all this game contains is creepy flirting and an abrupt ending. It's not an enjoyable experience, it's a thoroughly frustrating one.
