reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, I honestly did. I thought the premise had some promise. I knew there was likely to be some kind of twist towards the end, probably that the guy was a catfish or something (I won't say here whether there was or not just in case anyone actually cares).

I love narrative games. I loved Gone Home to bits and recommended it to everyone I knew. But this?

GAMEPLAY:

This has about the same amount of gameplay as Gone Home, but it feels like much less, and not just because it's only half the length. Half the game is spent clicking through files on this girls desktop, and the other half is spent playing a game that feels like someone tried to recreate Diablo in Adobe Flash as their first programming project. And it controls really badly. How they managed to muck up the simple act of clicking I'll never know - it lags like hell and just makes everything really frustrating. There is no depth to the game within the game whatsoever. Enemies cannot hurt you. There is no loot or customizability. You just click. Click on enemies. When the boss appears click on it. You don't even have to click more than once. Just give it a tap and you'll kill it 'till it's dead. There are no powerups, experience points, or special attacks. Just clicking.

STORY:

This is apparently based on an experience the writer (and lead actress) actually had. The problem is that it isn't an interesting experience. It's something that happens all the time and honestly wasn't even made that special by it happening online. The ending is disappointing. The acting is stilted and unconvincing, and the writing is mediocre at best.

OVERALL:

A genuine 0/10. It's not offensively bad, it simply has no redeeming qualities whatsoever and is a complete waste of time. It's only an hour long at most (I spent ~70 minutes because I used up some time complaining to a friend about it) and not a single minute of that hour is worthwhile.

Don't buy this game. If you get it in a bundle, don't redeem it. If you're given it as a gift, don't accept it. If somehow it ends up in your library, don't download it. If somehow it gets downloaded anyway, don't play it. I can think of absolutely no reason that anyone, for any reason, should play this game for any length of time whatsoever.

reviewText:
The best way I could describe this game is that it tries too hard to make its story feel deep and make some comment on first love, and it doesn't try hard enough to make the gameplay that is offered interesting.

The story is pretty standard, it's basically two unlikeable cringe-lords falling in and out of love playing the most boring online game in existance. Most of the story is dispensed through dialogue between Nina and Ichi, and their conversations are boring. When you get right down to it, the story is basically girl and boy fall in love with eachother online, they meet up IRL and have sex, and then boy does not love girl anymore. That's pretty much it.

Mentioned previously the gameplay is pretty bland and boring. It consists mostly of clicking on enemies and watching your character auto-attack them, and pretty much this gameplay only serves as a way to slowly dispense story over the course of the game.

The worst part about this Cibele though is that it would work much better as a 30 minute or so short film instead of a 70 minute video game experience. But even if it was a short film, it wouldn't fix that the story is boring and is happening to unlikeable characters. This is defenitely not worth the $9 for full price.

If you want a good game in the style of Cibele though, I would suggest Emily is Away, which is a free game with a better story.

reviewText:
WELP, THAT WAS AWKWARD.

I'm glad this came in a bundle and I feel sorry for people who bought this at full price. The game is about an hour long, but it felt like an eternity..

The story is about an awkward girl who falls in love with an asshat in a crappy online game. And these kids get THIRSTY! So they meet up.  After sleepin' together mr. asshat realizes he don' luv hur.  The end.

The story isn't the biggest dealbreaker for me - I can appreciate lame-story-games like Gone Home etc. But the crapfest that the 'game within the game' offers really bumped this down. I get that it's not supposed to be an actual game, but they could have done something a little bit more.. dynamic. This had potential to be a game with an interesting narrative but everything falls flat when the gameplay feels like an obligation.

So unless you like lame and awkward: I don't recommend this game.

reviewText:
I have to admit that I feel guilty writing a bad review for an indie game. It must take a great deal of effort to manage to pull one off, and I hate to bash those efforts, however I have to be honest...

I saw the trailer of the game and was immediately intrigued by the game's prospects - considering that I had gone through a somewhat similar (but at the same time very much different) experience myself.

[Concept]

As you start the game you are presented with the computer's desktop from which you can navigate around some of your files and ultimately open up the game within which the story mostly revolves. As soon as you enter the game, you get a call request from Ichi. From there on you play together and the story (and their relationship) progresses from thereon.

The recipe is pretty much the same: you are presented with the desktop, you optionally check some files, play the game in order to get the story going, you get a small cutscene and the game fast-forwards a bit and the story repeats itself. You are presented with the desktop...

[Programming]

If memory serves me right, the programming was done by a single person, however I don't think that this is an excuse for how unpleasant the end-result was. Starting off with the OS, you would instantly feel better that you don't really use that in real life. Clicking on directories and pictures opens them up in new tabs all over the screen. There is no consistency as to where these windows open - and you cannot drag the windows around. So you can easily end up with windows over each other or elsewhere. You cannot navigate from one photo to the other without opening the file with a click, closing it and moving on the next one. A lot of unnecessary mouse movement and clicking for a relatively simple task. If you decide to open up all the files at once and then going through them you may end up with the images not opening up (a cap on the maximum number of open windows or bug?) or sometimes downright impossible since windows may show up over the directory.

These are just some minor annoyances with what presents itself as on OS. However it gets much worse when you 'play' the game itself. All you have to do is move around, attack random targets (and get Ichi to help you) until the boss appears. You land a couple of hits on it, it disappears, and you repeat the cycle until eventually you defeat it. This could have worked out Ok, but in my opinion it was really dragging and annoying. I am aware the that the 'game' itself isn't the main aspect of the game, but that doesn't really excuse. I have played Dear Esther, and for a game in which all you do is walk, I thought it was an amazing experience (even though it got its fair share of hate from others). The character movement is clumsy, the terrain is ragged and can lead to unpleasant collisions and the AI is just horrible. Ichi can defeat the game's terrain and move around in places which I cannot. Ichi also sometimes just runs off the screen and later reappears near you. The attack animations are mind-numbingly repetetive that even simply clicking to attack the enemies feels like a chore. When I finally get the boss to appear, given how fed up I would have already been at this point, I just click as fast as I can possibly can to attack it. However clicking rapidly slows down the game and mouse movement (I don't think this is intentional) and most of the time the character just moves around to the cursor position instead of attacking the boss. All in all, I'm not even sure I was really dealing damage to the boss or if it was set to just self-destruct on its own. That is how pointless I felt to the game (...not to mention Ichi's positive remarks about how well you play the game... it made me feel like I wanted to hit myself).

[Graphics]

Moving on... I don't really think I can complain here. The game doesn't really focus on visual effects or such, but presents aesthetically pleasing graphics. The 'game' is actually really beautiful for an abstract form of game genre. The desktop itself is also relatively well laid out. I think two minor aspects that could have used more polish would be the menu buttons and how the subtitles appear on top of the game.

[Audio]

I'm pretty sure I'm wrong here but I can only recall one song being present. Regardless, the main theme song was pretty haunting and an excellent choice for the game in my opinion.

[Story]

This is where I still struggle. On one hand it presents a life and love experience through online games and user interaction - which is what the game really presents itself as being about. A little bonus would be that through the files scattered on the desktop, you can get some backstory about the character. The mail and chat messages seem as compulsory to get the story going forward, and are very distracting from playing the 'game'. The story starts off well in my opinion but then as the game fast-forwards and the whole tone of the game changes you end up feeling like you missed out on something important which has really changed the relationship atmosphere.  When the characters finally met up IRL , the cutscene was way too dry, acted out and bereft of any emotions, which is really an anti-climax considering that the players have been investing their time just for the narrative and emotional attachment with the characters in the game.

All in all, considering the points mentioned above, it felt like the game set out to share a life experience but somehow got lost along the way. In the end you end up 'playing' a game which is both repetitive and boring just to get the story moving. You are then presented with a developing relationship that starts off fine and then ends up being too superficial and surreal, while near the end the user is left wondering why  Ichi became so distant and avoidant, and what you might have missed out on during the time. I understand how people sometimes become avoidant when present with stressful situations (such as travelling and commitment),  but it really feels as if the player missed out. I honestly cannot recommend this game.

@Nina - if you are reading this, I'm sorry for leaving a negative review. Thank you for sharing your experience with us, and if any of it is true and based on your real life, then I suppose I'm also sorry for what you've been through. Note that I am not bashing the experience itself, but rather how it has been presented to others. I still congratulate you for the efforts you've put into this and the little bonus info (found on the desktop files) about Cibele / you.

reviewText:
WELP, THAT WAS AWKWARD.

I'm glad this came in a bundle and I feel sorry for people who bought this at full price. The game is about an hour long, but it felt like an eternity..

The story is about an awkward girl who falls in love with an asshat in a crappy online game. And these kids get THIRSTY! So they meet up.  After sleepin' together mr. asshat realizes he don' luv hur.  The end.

The story isn't the biggest dealbreaker for me - I can appreciate lame-story-games like Gone Home etc. But the crapfest that the 'game within the game' offers really bumped this down. I get that it's not supposed to be an actual game, but they could have done something a little bit more.. dynamic. This had potential to be a game with an interesting narrative but everything falls flat when the gameplay feels like an obligation.

So unless you like lame and awkward: I don't recommend this game.

reviewText: Cibele is...not really a game? It's an experience, a story, a short (~1 hour), poignant, and unflinchingly intimate one. It's young love and sex in the internet age: kids making mistakes together, learning about themselves and each other. Exploring Nina's computer -- seeing her photos, reading her conversations and emails and poetry -- is like seeing someone naked; not in a sexual way, but stripped bare, essentially human. Hearing her talk to Ichi, sensing the mixture of hesitation and eagerness on both sides of their conversation, knowing what will come and how it will affect the girl whose shoes you've stepped into...it's an experience unlike any other I've had in gaming. I remembered what it meant to be like to be young and in love like that, willing to forego everything else in pursuit of that one person, and felt a little hint of that long-ago glow -- along with a little embarrassment and wistfulness.\n\nSo, for a straight review: it's not a game. Don't look for gameplay. But as a story -- a very raw and intimate one -- I thought my hour with Cibele was one well-spent. I am happy that I picked it up as part of a Humble Bundle, though; $9 may be a little steep of an asking price. But I'd pay $5 for the experience easily, so keep an eye out for sales!

reviewText:
An interestingly immersive experience. It definitely hits home if you have had any degree on an online relationship/ long distance, etc. Good play time (right under an hour, if you don't dally) and a very real reflection on the emotional rollercoaster that is tied to these relationships.

The actually game with Cibele is the worst part, quite boring, to be honest, and while it's clearly meant as an immersive tool while the player listens to conversations between Nina and Blake, I found myself annoyed and bored by the gameplay.

But still, other than that last bit, I enjoyed the experience. (Now, for $9, I'm not sure, but I got lucky with a humble bundle, so I'm content).

reviewText:
--- This review might contain some spoilers! ---

So what have we got here?
Well, first of all, you should be aware that this isn't really a game. It is much more a short movie (played it through in less than an hour) offering you a tiny bit of interaction.

The story itself is about a young woman who met - and eventually fell in love with - a handsome boy" she is playing with all the time. As the story progresses they find out they feel attracted to each other. Finally they decide to meet and discover what their relationship will bring.

Sad thing here is not the little interaction nor the low budget acting. All this might still offer an interesting experience.
Main problem with this story is... there is none! All that happens is very linear. The conflict - both (but more from his side) don't really know what to expect from their relationship - is just beginning when the story already ends.
Don't get me wrong. Probably many people (not only those who share the high interaction with other players in online MMORPO games) know this conflict.
But sadly the story fails in a broader "discussion" of this issue. This is most obvious when the story actually ends the moment it just begins. When the boy finally took the chance to visit the protagonist
date: they meet the first time outside the game. It leads to the predictable conflict that was prepared the scene before. So there was no big surprise. But this should be the moment when the story starts - not their end.\nThe movie does not offer any solution
recommended: nor does it show the conflict from another point of view. There is no progress for the progtagonists. Neither in overcoming their shared conflict (of not being together) nor in how to deal with being hurt by someone important for you (the first love).\nSo when the game ends
hoursPlayed: it leaves all this to you. This is pretty unsatisfying. Not because it would make you think. No
voteText: this would be actually a great effect. But more
helpfulPercent: because it does not give you any new input. You might know this problem by yourself or not. And when the ending credits are shown
votesHelpful:
you merely know that there are other people who share your type of memories.
Is that necessarily a bad thing? Not at all. But it doesn't offer you much more than this.

Don't get me wrong. The game also shares some nice moments. The voice acting is okay
votesTotal: gives you some authentic emotional moments. The art style is also somehow interesting (even though not amazingly great).\n\nSo
votesFunny: if you are up to watch a short movie where you have to make some clicks in order to continue an authentic story about first love with a sad ending
commentsCount: this might be an hour of gameplay for you.\nIf you expect a real interactive story
column16: or would be frustrated playing a story which ends where it actually just began

reviewText: Short game that took less than an hour to complete. I enjoyed the story, but felt it was going to have a bit more meat to it instead of ending as quickly as it did. The subject matter is important and discusses both the highs and lows of online dating. There isn't much gameplay to speak of as you're just listening to the two protagonists voice chat with each other for the entire duration of the game. I barely spent any money on this as it was part of the Humble Bundle, so I can't really complain. Cibele is like watching a short film that some gamers can relate to: Romance sometimes makes it so your interactions with others are put on hold as you search for that perfect someone in this crazy digital world.

reviewText:
I am not sure if I should give this a positive or not. On one hand I got this game for $1 along 2 others but it's only 1 hour of repetitive gameplay.

+ Pros
-Slightly above average acting

+ A decent game in a game

+ Gives an immersive experience

Negatives
- Akward delivery of lines

-no replay value

-Based on true story

-Repetive gameplay

The reason I put based on a true story as a negative is because I feel like this game could have been a multiple ending game. With it being a true story it can only be that story otherwise it would be an adaptation of the story. This game ultimately from linarity.

My final conclusion is that it is worth the $1 and definetly not worth $8. $2 being the most I would pay.

reviewText:
This was a very relatable story to me because I've known many people that have been through something almost like this.  To me, I've really only seen the story line that it immediately was given.  I didn't delve deep into the poems and websites that the game offered, but I skimmed over them to get to know a little about our character.
The game play... was repetitive.  It was a MMO style where you click on monsters and kill them.  To me, that isn't my cup of tea.  I was glad that the story didn't last a super long time.
In the end, I do like the game, but it’s not a 9 dollar game.  I only got this game because it was in a Humble Bundle pack.  For the price, I certainly do not recommend this game.  I can get enough of this storyline from my Facebook Page.

reviewText: This game seems to capture the mind of 12 to 14 year olds.  The silly poetry, the incessant self-conciousness, the immaturity, the pink here there and everywhere.  But the protagonist is 19, which sets the tone at odds with the characters.\n\nI found this story and the dialogue to be cringe-worthy, though not unbelievable given the vapidity of young people. I suppose looking back we can all see our younger selves and think What in god's name did you do and say that for? What kind of unknowing
date: unseeing child are you?"\n\nThe characters struck me as such: Adult children.  Perhaps the game is a statement on such things.  I'm not sure
recommended: all I know is this game barely held my attention and I am fortunate to have gotten it on the Humble Bundle like many others.\n\nPerhaps the writer would be better off writing for a film rather than a video game.  If the writer's age is hinted at in the game

reviewText:
True story or not, this is a perfect opportunity for a game to show proper emotional development.
But the outcome is quite boring and (excruciatingly) awkward to listen too.
I'm not sure if people talk like this in real life, maybe i'm just not in the same group as the represented characters.

Extended:
The gameplay itself is clunky and boring, however I think that is deliberate to focus attention towards the writing and browsing of background items.
While there's some small touches on character and relationship changes, it's barely noticable to have any impact on what you think overall.
Basically this entire hour long segment could be equally (Actually I think better) explored in a 3-5 minute read personal blog post.

As you've probably already read in other reviews, this game is about a young girl who falls in love with a guild mate and they meet up. He promptly ditches her after they meet up in real life, and that's the end.

The MMO's gameplay is choppy, and Cibele's character doesn't move around very well. Other than that, the story is mildly interesting, and the acting is okay.

It was worth the .33 cents it ended up costing after buying it in a 1 dollar humble bundle.
